author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He had been hiding his eyes with the other hand since he started crying.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And now he was crying even harder.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I kept squeezing his thin, dry hand.The heat in his palm made me think that sometimes it’s too late, some things can’t be fixed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t know anything about his past, but I had the sense that long ago, someone had abused him sexually.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He had been completely crushed, pushed to a point where there was no hope he would ever recover—or maybe it was just a matter of giving it time, I thought.I felt bad for having spoken so flippantly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s so easy to be insensitive about things you have no personal experience of.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I couldn’t even guess what it was that had gone wrong inside him.No doubt every little thing I did to try and help him feel better, things any woman would do, only drove him further into a corner.At the same time, seeing how extremely sweaty his face had become when he made his confession earlier had left me feeling a little frightened myself, like he was telling me more than I needed to know.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Right now I was still too exhausted, too wasted to start anything new, but after a little while I hoped I could fall in love, and have more fun, and be young.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Go to the movies, argue, meet up somewhere, go out to eat (even though Nakajima didn’t like eating out), do all that, wasting time in a nice way.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s what I wanted to do.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t want to deal with weighty matters.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s what I was hoping for, except that if I were to go out with him it seemed unlikely we could ever go to a hot springs together, and simply having sex would be an ordeal.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That would really be a pain.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I mean, I want to have fun with my life, I thought.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because I was still able, at that point, to treat it all lightly.And then, peering at me with the eyes of a boy in elementary school, his voice stuffy from crying, Nakajima spoke.“Is it all right if we try?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If we see if I can do it?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If I can’t now, I feel like I never will.”Okay, if you want, I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And that was it.He said he’d be too scared if we were naked, so we fumbled over each other’s bodies in our pajamas.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Nakajima was kind of oddly built, and he didn’t really seem to be enjoying himself.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It felt like I was faking sex with a person who thought sex was a bad thing.The whole time, I kept thinking that it would take a pretty major shift in perspective for me to start wanting to go on doing this with this guy, and that made it even more bizarre.But occasionally something in our movements flashed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was hope.Those are my memories of our first night together.After I said goodbye to my mom, my life seemed to turn rapidly in a new direction.I no longer had to go back to my hometown all the time and Nakajima had begun coming over, and everything happened so suddenly … day after day, it was like living out some weird fantasy.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Like I was inhabiting someone else’s dream, some stranger’s.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Did all that really happen?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I wondered, dazed, casting my mind back.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: To her bones, the crematorium.And then I got offered a big job.I was a fledgling painter, you see, who specialized in murals.My palette was unusual, unlike other painters’, so every so often my work got featured on TV programs and stuff, and since I was happy to go anywhere, all on my own—except that I often had to hire a student to take me, since I don’t drive—I had gotten a decent number of jobs, here and there.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s not like I was famous or anything, but there’s always a demand for that kind of work, more than you’d expect, and so I was constantly going off to do a mural on the side of someone’s house or in a garden, on a crumbling wall outside an aquarium, on the side of a shed owned by a neighborhood association.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The main point, as far as I was concerned, was to put my pictures outside, so as a rule I didn’t agree to requests regarding the subject matter.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I would talk things over with people, and to some extent I’d take general suggestions, like if someone said they wanted fruit, or animals, or the ocean or something.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So far I had painted about twenty pictures on walls, warehouses, and playground equipment.That said, I wasn’t passionately committed to earning a living this way or anything.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I tried it once and people liked it, so I kept doing it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s all there was to it.Basically, I just liked the lifestyle I had when I was painting my murals.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t think my work necessarily had much value as art.Sooner or later they were bound to be destroyed or painted over for bureaucratic reasons, after all, so there was no point obsessing over details.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: All I wanted was to have fun painting, to chat and make friends with people who came by while I worked, and for my mural to add just a little bit of warmth to the lives of the people in the vicinity.The wall I’d been asked to paint this time was on the grounds of my old art school.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was a fairly low wall that divided the campus from a place that used to be a preschool and was now a privately run Infant Development Center.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was already a mural on the art-school side, one from a long time ago, but the side facing the center was just plain yellow.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The people who hired me said I could paint whatever I wanted there.I had nice memories of the building itself, since it was near my school and I had seen it all the time when I was taking classes, so I accepted the job immediately when an old classmate of mine, Sayuri, offered it to me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She was the center’s piano teacher.The building that housed the center was a bit old but really charming: it had been designed by an architect who grew up in the neighborhood, and he had worked hard to make it special so that future generations of children could go to school in a fresh, innovative structure.Even when I was a student, I’d loved the center, I loved it more the more I saw it—the shape of the walls; the contour of the building itself; the yard, specially landscaped for children, with a little manmade hill—and I used to have my lunch leaning against that wall, watching the kids.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The building had such an aura of warmth to it that I thought if I had been young enough, I would have wanted to go to school there myself.Apparently it was getting dangerously run-down, though, and since it would cost a fortune to fix it up, someone had suggested that the whole structure be torn down.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: A TV crew came to report on it and everything.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They presented it as the story of a community trying to save a local building and a painter they had hired to help.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I agreed to do an interview.I wasn’t particularly involved with the political stuff, though.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just wanted to have fun with the kids who had to pass by to get in and out of the building, and to look into their eyes, and put the things I saw in them up on that wall.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I figured this job would keep me busy all spring; beyond that, I couldn’t say.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There’s no point thinking about the future.That’s what it’s like when you’re creating things.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: On the one hand, it really seems like you’re keeping it all moving on your own, and you can tell yourself that you’ve got inspiration raining down on you, but ultimately you can’t make anything happen on your own.I knew the kids would make it work.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They would help me put something eternal onto that wall.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Something that would last forever, even if the wall did end up being knocked down.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And that was enough for me.I’d been through so many unfamiliar things recently, looking after my mom and managing her funeral and so on, and it was like this worldly grime had rubbed off on me from dealing with all that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I wanted to wash it all away, throwing myself into my work.Caring for my mom had taken all the energy I had, and I hadn’t had the mental space to think of anything but how overwhelmed I was.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’d always felt that I was striving for something good, though, reaching toward the light, and so it really hadn’t been that bad.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Things had come to feel so normal that I could hardly believe it when I would remember I couldn’t call her up to talk whenever I wanted to anymore, about whatever was on my mind.I had always been thinking about her, about what I could do for her, but she would be unconscious, or in a daze, out of it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That was what really hurt.The meeting that afternoon went smoothly.I had a pleasant discussion with the managers of the Infant Development Center—a couple who had worked, apparently, in a preschool in the United States—and we agreed that I would paint a cheery group of animals or something along those lines.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was a bit troubled by the bumpiness of the wall, but it would take too long and be too expensive to fill in all the depressions, and I had the feeling I could obviate the need by brushing on a heavy undercoat.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was nothing but dirt in front of the wall, so I wouldn’t even have to spread a plastic sheet.These things would make the work a lot easier, and it sounded as if the local government could help out financially; I’d have about five hundred thousand yen, which was enough to allow me to hire a driver for at least a few days.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Having a helper would make things much easier: it was a boon to have a car, of course, and he could help me lug the twenty or so cans of water-based paint I’d need back and forth every day.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I got permission to borrow the school’s ladder, and with a bit of luck it sounded as if I might be able to leave my tools in the storage room, as long as there was space.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Everything was getting off to a good start.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: When you’re working at a semipublic site like this, the least bit of friction at the beginning can make things drag on and on.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It looked as though things were going to work out this time.I wonder if Nakajima will come stay over tonight, too?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I thought as I stood gazing down the length of the wall, all alone.I wasn’t exactly excited, but I felt a warm glow inside.I felt like someone with a brand-new boyfriend.Sometimes, though, I imagined what it might be like if I happened to fall passionately in love with someone else, and it became inconvenient to have Nakajima around.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: What would I do then?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: At the moment, I wasn’t really sure.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He’d had a tremendous influence on me, that was true, but that seemed kind of different from being head over heels in love.Right now it wasn’t really an issue, because I was enjoying myself, but it would be a pain if something like that happened after we had become more deeply involved.And what would happen to Nakajima if I did meet someone else and just chased him out?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: How did I know he wouldn’t kill himself, or go crazy?I couldn’t begin to imagine how someone like him, with his awful past, might feel because I had never suffered any terrible wounds.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Of course, it would be even worse if I thought I could understand.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Recognizing how totally ignorant you are is the only honest way to deal with people who’ve been through something traumatic.Still, I had the feeling it would be okay.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I would go on liking Nakajima.I had taken such great care to reach this point, and now, little by little, I was falling in love.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Even putting it in conservative terms, it would probably be fair to say that I needed him—no one else would do.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I had the sense that he was the one.It’s like when you decide to build a house: some people want to go and find the land first, then hire an architect to help them draw up the plans, and then choose the materials for the walls and everything all on their own.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m not like that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I prefer to wander around until I stumble across something, then do the best I can with it, scrutinizing this thing I’ve discovered, getting to know it for what it is.By the same token, some muralists will neatly fill in all the joints in a wall, transform it into a perfectly white canvas, come up with a motif that harmonizes with the colors around the wall, then carefully block out the sketch on their pad and enlarge it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s one method.But I’m not that type at all.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just lose myself in the joy of painting, getting the picture up there, and if something goes wrong in the creative process I find a way to fix it and finish the project, no matter what.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m a real believer in working on site, and I’ll be there no matter what’s going on in my life, and I don’t put any stock in whatever it is that happens inside my head.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I look, I sense time passing, I move my body, and I try as much as possible to stay outside.And usually, when it’s all over, I find that everything has come together surprisingly well.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: When that happens, I feel like I’ve been dancing, perfectly in time, with the world.That sense of having partnered with the environment, the land, of moving, entranced … and then I say goodbye to it all forever, and head for the next location.Sure, I knew perfectly well that my way was sloppy.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But for me, at that point, painting murals was more like a hobby than anything else; it wasn’t a true profession.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So I was content with what I did.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: At some point I would have to decide whether or not to make this my occupation, and I assumed that as time passed, the problems that arose because I did things this way would sort themselves out in a manner that was right for me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And who knew, maybe in the process I’d become a professional painter.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I figured that if I could refine my method as much as possible, and if things went as well as I hoped, I was bound to produce good results.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So I just kept pushing quietly ahead.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s the stage I was at then.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was still at the very beginning.Of course, some people criticized me for doing things the way I did.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Look at her, they’d say, painting those childish pictures, she has practically no technique, and then she has the nerve to do interviews as if she were some kind of famous artist!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Stuff like that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But there was one area, just one, where I had honed my abilities to perfection, and I held to that absolutely.Since I was painting my pictures outside, I would think and think, extremely hard, until I was sure that even decades later my work wouldn’t look out of date.If I focus very hard, right at the beginning, on the scenery and the spirit that runs through the place, I start to get an image of colors and the motif that are right for it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: As long as I don’t misread that, as long as I manage to put myself in complete harmony with my surroundings, and as long as I don’t lose my concentration, the picture I paint will last ten years, twenty years, maybe even a hundred without looking dated.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s the one ability I have faith in.Just as the head carpenter takes pride in the house he’s built, I had made up my own mind, consciously, that I was right about this.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That was settled, and I stuck to my guns.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was never wishy-washy about that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I stood up to the world, and I made my little mark.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sort of like a dog, I guess, pissing someplace to show it had been there.I don’t know if it’s appropriate to treat these things like they’re part and parcel of being in love, but Nakajima and I never talked about preparations or plans, even dreams.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We just kept going on as we were, here and now.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The two of us, on location.I couldn’t do anything.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because I could tell—I felt it.No one else is like Nakajima.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: No one in the world is as peculiar as he is.I’d never seen anyone who looked the way he did standing by the window at night, so thin and detached.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He didn’t have the slightest faith in this human society of ours; he stood on the outside looking in.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was something sad in his posture, and something strong, and I wanted to go on watching him forever.Looking back now, I can see that the way I sat gazing at his silhouette against the window in those days, I might as well have been a girl in junior high with a crush on some boy.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I wanted so badly to hold his image in my mind’s eye.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: How can he look so beautiful just standing there, I wondered.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And that’s really all it was.It hits so hard …I was staring up through leafless branches.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They were spread out like a hand, and that special, weak light particular to the time when winter ends and spring gets under way was filtering down through them.I used to come to this school every day, so I knew this place through and through.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t need to worry that I’d paint something weird.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But still, just in case, I kept standing there.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ll make the picture a little bit sad, and a little happy, I thought.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Already, like a lovely shadow, a hazy image began to project itself upon the wall.“Heading home, Chihiro?”It was Sayuri, the woman who had gotten me the job.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I assumed she had just finished one of her piano lessons.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She must be taking a break, I supposed, before the next stream of kids comes in the evening.I love feeling the rhythm of other people’s lives.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s like traveling.“Not necessarily,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “You want to go to a café?”“I don’t think I have time for that,” Sayuri said.So I gave her one of the two cans of coffee I’d bought earlier.“Still thinking about that guy?” Sayuri continued.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “The weirdo.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The thin one.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Smart, going to college.”“Yeah, that’s right.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I told you a little about him, I guess?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Nakajima.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m not just thinking about him anymore, actually—I think we’re dating, kind of.”“What did you say he studies?”“He said something about research on chromosomes, but I have to confess I have no idea what that means in terms of what he actually does.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Right now he’s working on an article about Down’s syndrome and the presence of chromosome 21 and what happens when you … I forget, he tried to explain it to me a couple times, but it was too complex, I didn’t get it at all.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Hardly a surprise, I suppose, seeing as he’s writing the article in English.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I couldn’t sneak a peek even if I wanted to.”“So it’s too complicated for even you to remember.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The main point is that you have no idea what the main point is—that much I get.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You seem to be getting along all right, though, even if you can’t make heads or tails of something that must matter a lot to him.”“It’s true, I know.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If only he were into cultural anthropology or folklore studies or French literature or something, it would be so much easier.…”“Then you’d be able to understand it, at least a little.”“Of course, sometimes it’s better not to understand.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I kind of like how our days are now.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I feel more at peace than I ever have,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Everything’s so calm, and quiet, and yet at the same time there’s something powerful—it’s like living underwater.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The rest of the world keeps seeming more and more remote.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s kind of like, I don’t know, I don’t imagine things will get any more exciting than they are now, but I can’t imagine us breaking up, either.”“You just started dating and already you feel that way?” Sayuri laughed.“I haven’t asked him about it,” I said next, “but it’s pretty clear that something happened to him, ages ago, something really bad.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But you know how it is when you’re with someone, you kind of figure stuff out, right?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So I decided there’s no hurry, I’m not going to rush him, and I guess now things have kind of settled into place.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Do you think I should ask him?”“I don’t see the need.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I mean, if things are going well.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just hope that whatever that awful thing is, it isn’t something really awful.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Like he committed a crime, or ran away from his debts, or went bankrupt.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Or maybe that would be okay, as long as it doesn’t become an issue now.”“Yeah, well, judging from his personality I’d say it probably isn’t anything like that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Who knows, maybe it’ll turn out not to be such a big deal.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He did tell me that he was really close to his mother, and it was a huge shock when she died.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I get the sense he’s been hurt in some way much deeper than that.”“I hope whatever it is isn’t still an issue.”“Oh, I think it is—I feel it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m just hoping it’s not so bad that he can’t go on living with it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And hey, he’s made it this far, right?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Maybe everything will be fine, and it’s just a matter of going on with his life, treating it as gently as possible.”I spoke like I was praying.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Please, I thought, keep living.Nothing I could ever do would relieve Nakajima of his pain.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That had only become clear once we started living together.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I had seen him wake up screaming in the middle of the night and bolt up, trembling; I’d seen him break into a sweat when he found himself in a crowd; I’d seen certain kinds of music give him terrible headaches; and I’d had to listen to him telling me that for a long time after his mother died, what he wanted more than anything was to follow her.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: These were just fragments, but the longer we were a couple, the more I saw.When there’s a plus, there’s always a minus.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If there’s a powerful light, the darkness that is its opposite will be just as strong.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: To me, Nakajima seemed like a creature in a legend, unable to control the forces raging within him.“In this line of work, I come into contact with kids who have all sorts of troubles,” Sayuri said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Some are just cruel by nature, and some have mental problems, but other than that I get the sense that usually it’s the parents who are the problem.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: When something happens with the parent of a really young child, something seems to get paralyzed inside, or broken, and even if it’s a really tiny part, it has to be built up again.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I see that pretty often.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s really true, there’s something huge in people like that that can’t be whitewashed over.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s like, you’re at a loss for what to do, because they’ve been broken in so many different ways, so subtly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m just a piano teacher so I don’t actually have to deal with that stuff, but if you’re a preschool teacher or something, you have to interact with the parents a lot more, and I just think that would be so hard.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There are so many messed-up families these days, too many.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Screwed-up parents.”I nodded.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Even out by the wall, where I was painting the mural, I could tell.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There were parents and children of a sort you never would have seen before, mixed in among all the rest.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t think Nakajima was one of them, though.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: His problem was different.“I know something happened to him, that much is clear, and it obviously wasn’t a subtle sort of thing.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There must have been some really big event in his past.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Only in his case—well, from what I can tell, his parents were divorced, but I don’t have the sense it was particularly acrimonious, you know, and I know his mother loved him really deeply, and it doesn’t seem like anything happened with her, so I don’t think it was a problem with his parents.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s the impression I get, judging from the bits and pieces I’ve heard.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Above all, Nakajima himself is just such a nice person.… I know I keep repeating myself, but really the only thing I can be sure of is that something appalling happened.”“Appalling?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Like how?”“Like he was kidnapped, or sexually abused, though not by his parents.”The moment I heard myself saying that, something clicked.Every so often, that happens.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I say it, and I realize it’s true.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Something close to an answer lay in the words I’d just spoken.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was convinced of it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I decided just to keep talking.“Anyway, he’s not like other people at all, it’s like, I don’t know how to describe it, like he’s living in the clouds, maybe.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Like when people talk about someone having transcended it all—he’s like that, I guess.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So part of me thinks it’s just in his makeup, and he would have been this way even if nothing had happened.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: For the time being I’ll just keep watching, I won’t rush it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He and I are the kind of people who need to take things slow anyway.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Getting to know each other, talking things through, everything has to go nice and slow,” I said.At some point, as I was talking, it hit me how deeply concerned about Nakajima I was.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That I wanted to know, sort of, except that at the same time I didn’t.That was why I felt this way.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: As if maybe, maybe, I was starting to commit.Maybe I’d begun to love him, maybe at some point I’d actually fallen for him in a big way.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: For the first time in my life I seemed to be in love, not just playing—a woman loving a man.I could tell because I was cautious, the way my mom had been with my dad.That’s how she was: the deeper she loved, the more hesitant she was.“How about money?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Does he have his own?”“Yes.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He says his father will keep supporting him until he finishes his Ph.D., and I guess he has whatever his mother left, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He still has his own apartment, but since he spends nights at my place he puts money in my account for food and utilities and stuff.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Every month.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And he calculates it all incredibly precisely.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Down to the hour, down to the yen.”“He’s good about those things, then.”“You’re pretty down-to-earth yourself, huh, asking about that?”“Well, anyway, it sounds to me like everything’s fine.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You can go on living together like you are for the rest of your lives.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s kind of weird, but then so are you.”“Yeah, I guess I’ll just let things progress this way for a while,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Thinking to myself, Assuming there’s any progress.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “But enough about that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You came out because you had something to talk about, right?”“Right.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I wanted to apologize.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: For making you go on TV, about the mural.”“Oh, don’t worry about it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I don’t mind.”“You’re really famous now, huh?” Sayuri said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Features on TV and everything.”I laughed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I’m certainly not really famous.”“In this part of town, that’s enough to make you a celebrity.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And a lot of people are hoping that now that you’re painting this mural, if your work attracts attention, maybe the building won’t be torn down after all.”“Hmm.”“I’m sorry.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t mean to get you involved.”“Which side are you on?”“Oh, I don’t want them to tear it down—of course not!” Sayuri said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I live for this center.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Lots of my students have been coming here for years.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s not why I suggested you, though.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just wanted to have one of your pictures here, a huge one, where I work.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s the truth.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I had no intention of using you, or of making you create something only to have it destroyed.”I knew Sayuri meant it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s the kind of person she is.She was staring at the ground.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I gazed at the fine hairs around her ears, her thick eyebrows, and I could feel how serious she was.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: No doubt all kinds of people had been pressing her to do all kinds of things, but she kept it all to herself, protecting me.“Really, I’m happy to do any number of interviews about the mural.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Only, when it comes to these other things, I don’t really understand the issues,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Sorry.”“Thanks for being so willing to help.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And on the off chance that this place should happen to be torn down sometime soon, and this wall goes with it, I’m really sorry,” Sayuri said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I’ll do everything I can to protect it, as long as I’m here.”“It’s okay,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I don’t paint for the future.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Besides, it’s not your fault.”“Either way, I’m planning to take a lot of pictures,” Sayuri said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “And I’ll have them keep copies in the district document center.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s something I’m definitely going to do.”I would have been lying if I’d said I didn’t care at all whether the mural survived.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But it’d be an even bigger lie to say I wanted it to survive forever.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just liked coming here and feeling things each day, and recording those feelings in a kind of big way in a picture.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That was how I saw what I was doing.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I guess my attitude was sort of casual.When I compared myself to Sayuri, who was so incredibly dedicated and so earnest in her dealings with the kids, I felt sort of bad.The truth was, it didn’t make any difference to me whether my mural was knocked down or admired or whatever.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And if the Infant Development Center closed, as long as the people there were good and smart, I felt sure they would carry on their work somewhere else.Maybe I was afraid of seeing anything as absolute.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I wanted to keep moving, like a stream, and I wanted to go on watching everything from a distance.That’s how I was.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I felt close to people, but I didn’t have any friends I could really share my life with, our hearts melting together.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Something always failed to communicate.Nakajima was the first true friend I’d ever had, in my whole life … I really believed that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He was extremely frail, and yet there was something in him I could trust.I saw myself reflected in our relationship, as if in a mirror.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And I knew that I wasn’t wrong.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And I was at peace.All along, just because I lived away from my mom, I thought I’d achieved independence, but now that she was gone I finally realized how much, in my heart, I had depended on her.I never asked my mom for advice, but whenever I was going through an unsettled period like I was now, I’d call her up to talk, or go back to visit, just to see her face.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Now that she was gone, I realized these little things had given me a core to hold on to—or maybe brought me back, for better or worse, to the place I came from.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I wasn’t even sure what that meant … whether that place was something that had existed before I was born, or not.When I was young, I used to turn and look back at my mother’s face to make sure I knew where I was in relation to her; now, I had to take stock of my situation by myself.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sure, I could see myself through Nakajima, but the second I glanced away I lost it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Parents are absolute; he wasn’t.I’d watched my mother dying for so long that now I could hardly remember how, back when she was healthy, her spirit used to shine.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: All that came to me now was the agonizing sound of her final breaths, the smell of her dying body that had filled the hospital room, things like that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The sense of powerlessness, knowing that my mom was suffering alone, and that in her universe I was no help at all—I could recapture that feeling, but nothing else.I read in some book that if you try to hold people back too much when they’re dying it keeps them from being reborn as a Buddha, and that had stuck with me, somehow, maybe more than it should have, so I tried hard not to cry too much, and kept telling my mom how much I appreciated all she had done for me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Now all I can do is think how stupid I was to act like that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I should have cried my eyes out.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I should have thrown myself wailing at the coffin the way my dad did, and made a huge commotion.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Forgotten everyone watching, the mourners and what they’d think, and just been myself.If I had done that, I bet my mom wouldn’t have come in my dream the way she did that night, worried because she saw that part of me was holding back, unwilling to fall completely in love with Nakajima.About two weeks after Nakajima first stayed over, he asked me for a favor.“I want to go see some old friends, but I’m scared to go alone.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Will you come?”We hadn’t had sex again since that first time, but he’d been staying over at my apartment every night.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He always made sure to remind me that he’d recalculate the utility bills.My mural-painting days wouldn’t start until the following week, so the timing was perfect.Since I had so much time on my hands, I’d been cooking all kinds of dishes using a huge package of imported gourmet ham that my dad had sent.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Fried rice with pineapple and ham, ham and steak, steamed rice with ham, and so on.I tried so many different ham recipes that finally even Nakajima, who really wasn’t particular about what he ate and generally was fine with anything, blurted out, “Can we have something besides ham tonight?”Other than that, all I did was go with the guy I’d hired to help me work on the mural—a guy I knew from art school, younger than me—to buy the paints and assemble the various brushes I’d need, and then I sat at my desk working on preliminary sketches.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was a pleasant time.I love sitting at my desk drawing—it’s like painting in miniature.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Since I never simply transfer my sketches to a wall, it’s all about getting a sense of the partially formed image I have in mind—I’m just doodling, basically.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But drawing on a small scale has its own particular pleasures.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s like when I used to play house as a kid.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Tiny little utensils, tiny little people.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And yet everything is blown up to actual size in my mind.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s the kind of pleasure I get out of drawing.The wall I’d be painting was long and low, so I planned to do something bold with a lot of monkeys linked in a kind of flow, but I was having a hard time envisioning a design for it, something that would look good and fit well with the site.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I couldn’t believe how poorly my imagination was serving me, and I started wondering if maybe it would be best to just go and start painting, or maybe take a survey of the kids.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was coming to the end of my rope.If I were just going to paint the sort of design an amateur could come up with, they might as well call in a bureaucrat from city hall to do the job.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There needed to be a touch of eeriness in it, something private.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But what?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: What sort of memories involving monkeys did I have—when, come to think of it, was the last time I had even seen a monkey?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Should I go to the zoo to see some?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Those are the kinds of issues I was grappling with.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So when Nakajima asked if I would accompany him, it sounded like a great way to get my mind out of its rut.“Sure,” I said, eyeing a magazine.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Maybe we can have a picnic on the way!”But when I glanced up and saw the expression on Nakajima’s face, the lighthearted feeling with which I’d replied withered.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I could see this was important to him.Until then, things had been going along the same as always, without any trace of progress.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We had gotten up that morning, shared an omelet that I’d made with our last eggs (and ham, needless to say); just then, I was sitting in a rather shocking pose, in the middle of doing my toenails, and Nakajima was tapping away on his PowerBook, working on a report.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’d just been thinking that when he got to a stopping place maybe I’d make some tea when he mentioned his friends and wanting to go see them.Sayuri had been right: Nakajima wasn’t like us.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She and I had gone to an art school that wasn’t very prestigious; he went to a university one district over that only people who are really, really good in school can get into.Naturally, I asked him about it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “How did you get so good at studying?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Did you like studying from the time you were little?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Was that it?”Nakajima sat thinking for a while without moving.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Then he said, “One day, all of a sudden, I felt this powerful urge to study, as if I were trying to get something back that I’d lost.”“Was that … after your mom died?” I asked.“Yes.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You see, during the time when I was away, my mother and father started arguing about all kinds of things, and then they started living apart, and in the end they divorced.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Since then I’ve been in a situation sort of similar to the one you’re in now—I still get living expenses and tuition and stuff, and I still go visit my father from time to time, and … well, anyway, the point is that I was in high school when my mother died, and I decided I didn’t want to go live with my dad.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I mean, he’d been living up in Gunma since the divorce—that’s the prefecture he grew up in—and I didn’t really feel like moving to a new place, just like that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He had remarried, too, and they had kids.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So I decided I’d live on my own, and then, well, I had enough money so it wasn’t like I had to work like mad to make ends meet or anything, and I’m certainly not a big spender, so all of a sudden I found myself with lots of time on my hands.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I thought a lot about what I should do.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I wanted something where I wouldn’t have to deal with people too much, and where I could keep my involvement to a minimum, so I’d be able to do my own stuff, and ideally I thought it’d be nice if I could make people’s lives better—that’s the life I wanted.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And after looking into various options, I settled on genetic research.”“But why would you want to pick something so difficult?” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Did you know someone around you who did the same kind of thing?”He paused awkwardly again before he continued.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Well, yeah.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: When I was away from my parents, the one adult I felt close to had graduated from a department like that with a degree in genetics, and hearing about the topic from him made me think it might be interesting to learn more.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And then after my mother died, I was all alone and I was depressed, and since I had nothing else to do I studied constantly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was totally obsessed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Of course, it was all focused on passing the entrance exams for university.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t want to deal with people, so I didn’t go to cram school or anything, I just did it all myself.”He went on to explain his methods in detail, at great length.I wanted to ask why he’d been separated from his parents, but I didn’t.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just listened.He said he taught himself to concentrate really fiercely, to cut his mind off from his body.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He found that it wasn’t all that hard, but he also discovered that it was a dangerous thing to do in the real world.The story was as strange as his tone was bland.By the time he got into the university he was aiming for, he weighed forty-five pounds less than he had before he started.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He had stopped being able to eat at all, and he collapsed on a road somewhere and found himself in the hospital.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They had to feed him through an intravenous drip—otherwise he wouldn’t have survived.“Sounds like the wrong way to go about becoming a doctor,” I said.He laughed like crazy at that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s true he’s in the graduate school of medicine at his university, but he said none of the students in his program are training to become doctors.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s a program for future researchers.Once Nakajima started studying he couldn’t stop, and his grades got even better when he figured out how to detach his mind from his body; he got so engrossed in what he was doing that he felt as if he could have forgotten about his body altogether.“The only thing was,” he said, “I realized then, in a pretty painful way, that there’s always a lag before the body responds to the orders the mind sends out.”“A lag?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: What do you mean?”“It was fairly easy in the beginning, when I’d do this self-hypnosis thing, setting it up so that my body would function at the absolute minimum and all the energy would get routed to my mind instead.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That much was no problem, and I guess that made me overconfident.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The catch was—I’m not sure how to explain it, but it’s like the process accelerated once it got underway, and even if I sent out the order to my body to engage again so that I could get some nutrition and move my limbs and stuff, even when I was really trying, it was like a merry-go-round, the way it can only stop very gradually, by spinning slower and slower.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I hadn’t taken that into account, and I had ignored my body too long, and so I stopped the merry-go-round too late.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I almost died.”“All right,” I said, “I realize that you can do that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But don’t, not anymore, okay?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It puts too much of a strain on your body.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You end up paying for it later on, right?”“That’s why I don’t study like that anymore.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I do just enough to keep up.”Nakajima smiled.Wow, I thought.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: This guy says he’s doing just enough to keep up, and he can still succeed in grad school, not to mention that whenever he’s not studying he’s writing another article or doing some sort of preliminary research, surveying the literature or something.… He must be really good at this academic stuff.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was impressed.“I studied my ass off all that time, and then one day, just like that, it hit me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m on track to finish my coursework, there’s no question about that, and as long as I keep at it with the articles I’ll definitely get my Ph.D. And then I can go on the market in Japan, and the chances are that there will be a good match somewhere, and I’ll find a position at some institute.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Only I’m not sure that the future will be all that bright if I just go on like this—if I stay here in Japan, I mean.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So I’ve been mulling things over.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I kind of think it might be good to go somewhere else.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That never occurred to me before.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Until now, it was all I could do just to stay alive.”All along, Nakajima’s tone had remained measured and easy.“That’s not anything I’d know about,” I said, “but if you’ve been able to manage this much, I’m sure you can do anything.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I mean it—anything.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You just have to put your mind to it.”Somewhere else.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I.e., somewhere outside Japan.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I.e.… we split up?So as far as he’s concerned, my apartment is just one step in the great escape?I had the feeling that it wasn’t yet time to talk about that.Nakajima had said he wanted to go see his friends, and yet whenever he talked about it his expression got incredibly gloomy.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So I asked him about it.“Do you feel a need to see these friends of yours now?”“No, it’s not that,” he said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I feel like maybe now I can.”“If I come along, you mean?” I asked.“Exactly … I mean, you’re so cheerful,” Nakajima said.“Maybe I’m not as cheerful as you think,” I replied.It wasn’t that I was annoyed; I just didn’t want to let him down.I had the feeling that Nakajima was taking one aspect of me—the straightforward, easy-going part that emerged when I was with him, the cheerful surface that I had inherited from my mom—and blowing it all out of proportion.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If so, he might feel terribly betrayed when my dark, somber side eventually showed its face.“No, I know that, it’s just … I know I can’t express it very well, no matter how I phrase it, but you’re just right.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: This sounds kind of odd, but your proportions are just right.”I sort of knew what he was trying to say.Considering how smart Nakajima was, I bet he could have found a way to express more precisely what it was like to push his body to the limit while studying, or his perspective on the way my emotions were structured inside me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He was just being nice, communicating on my level.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s what made it sound vague.Still, I had the sense that right then it helped for him to be talking about something, and so I decided to draw him out.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I intentionally cocked my head slightly, feigning puzzlement.“I mean, for you love is more important than anything else, right, Chihiro?” Nakajima said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “But you don’t try to control other people, do you?”“I guess that’s pretty true,” I replied.“And you cherish the memory of your mother?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Of course, everyone has little knots in their hearts, no matter what their families are like—but wouldn’t you say that in your case you feel love and hate in ordinary, healthy amounts?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Even if one may seem a bit stronger at times?”“Yeah, I’d agree with that.”“And you don’t hate your father, do you?”“No, I don’t.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If anything I think he’s kind of lovable.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The environment we lived in wasn’t ideal, but I suspect that it actually made it easier for us to express our love than in your average family.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We didn’t fit into any ready category, so we all had to work that much harder.”“Exactly—you don’t have that sense that you can take your family for granted, that’s why I feel so comfortable with you.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You see your family members for what they are, and you look at me in an ordinary way, without wishing that I was somehow different,” Nakajima said, his tone very level.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “That’s what I like about you.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m extremely, almost pathologically sensitive to violence, and I pick up on it immediately when something violent is happening.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Most people are constantly perpetrating little acts of violence on others, even when they don’t mean to.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You almost never do that, Chihiro.”“How about you?” I asked.“I’ve never been able to discuss this before,” Nakajima said, “but honestly, I felt oppressed the whole time until my mother died, because of the way she was always fretting over me—no one else mattered.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She became so focused on me that ultimately my father got fed up and left.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It really weighed down on me, but at the same time certain things had happened to keep us apart for a long time, and during that whole period I’d yearned to see her so badly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But then when we were finally reunited, when she was actually there, in person, her love completely overwhelmed me.… Like, if I was going out for a while, she couldn’t rest easy unless she’d checked to see when I’d be coming home, and if I was even a minute late she would be waiting up, crying, you know?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s the kind of woman she was.“And to make matters even worse, she died before we’d had time to live together as long as most mothers and sons do, and so I felt even more confused.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I have these two different images of her etched into my memory: one as this idealized mother, and the other as a sort of pressure weighing down on me—obsessive, feminine love.“The ideal side of her, though—that part of her was so extraordinary, it just blew me away, and I felt so small beside her, and I know that if it hadn’t been for her I wouldn’t even be here today.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m so grateful to her that if she were still alive, I could spend my whole life trying to pay her back and it would never be enough.“There was one time in particular when things got really terrible.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was a period when we were like a couple in love, lost in our own maze with no way out.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We were both going regularly to the hospital then, and we were in such bad shape that our doctor suggested we go and spend some time in a small house that belonged to some relatives of ours.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was a run-down shack way out in the country with nothing around it, and we did stay there for a while, living a quiet life.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was cool in the summer, but in the winter it got incredibly cold, we were always freezing, but the scenery was gorgeous, you could always see the lake, and it was lonely, and beautiful.“And now those friends of mine, the people I’ve been talking about, they live there now, and I want to go see them, I’ve been trying, but whenever I think about it—just look at me, you can see how it makes me sweat.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ve thought about going any number of times these past few years, but every time I end up making all sorts of excuses to myself, and in the end I decide not to go.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: No matter how hard I try, I can’t for the life of me figure out what it is that makes me break out in a sweat like this—my memories of my mother, or the memories I share with my friends.”“If it brings back such painful memories, maybe you don’t need to go,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Why don’t you just wait until it starts to feel right?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Don’t force it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Go when you’re ready.”Nakajima looked miserable when I said this.“If I do that, I won’t ever get to see them.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ll never see my friends again.”“When’s the last time you met?” I asked.“I haven’t been out since before my mother died, she and I visited together … it’s been about ten years, I guess.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Maybe longer.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Though occasionally I call,” Nakajima said.“You really want to see them?”“I really do, more than anything else in the world,” Nakajima said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I want to see them so badly I can’t stand it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: All the time.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Lately, now that I’m with you, I’ve been feeling more desperate than ever to see them, like I can’t hold myself back anymore.”“And how many friends are we talking about?” I asked.“Two,” Nakajima said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “They’re brother and sister, both old friends.”I had no idea where Nakajima wanted to take me, but I trusted him implicitly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I trusted him with my whole body, even with my skin.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: When you’re with someone every day, if there’s even the tiniest glimmer of a contradiction inside them, you pick up on it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Nakajima was an uneven sort of character, it was true, but he always struck me as totally sincere.“All right, then, let’s go.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Is it far?”“About three hours, including changing trains.”“Will it be expensive?”“I’ll pay.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m the one dragging you along, after all.”“That’s okay.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ll enjoy the trip, too.”“No, I should get the tickets and everything.”“Really, I’m in pretty good financial shape now.” I laughed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I’ve got a job.”“Why are you so willing to go with me, anyway?” Nakajima said, looking a bit surprised.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “You don’t even know where it is.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’d never be able to go on a trip like that.”“It’s someplace you really want to go, right, even though it hurts?” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “It’s only natural that I come along, if I’m the only person who’s able to help you do that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: After all, you’re here in my apartment every day.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We see each other all the time, and we’re together because we like being together, not because we have to be.”If I were really in love, I don’t think I could have said that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I probably would have tried to toy with his feelings a bit more, or maybe I would have had trouble finding the words.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But all I felt then was a desire to help.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And while I didn’t yet know the reason, it frightened me much more to think of him getting hurt than it did to think of someone else getting hurt.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Just the idea made me shudder, and left me feeling as if a heavy stone had lodged in my chest.“Thank you,” Nakajima said quietly.The next day, we took a train headed north.We got off at a small station and started walking.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was still a chill in the air—it was the sort of weather that makes your face feel cold, but doesn’t do anything more than that.From time to time, a cool ray of sunlight shone through the clouds.There were trees everywhere, their new leaves just beginning to appear.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Even the greenest branches were dotted, here and there, with sensuous, round buds, clenched but swelling, vibrant in the haze of fresh growth.

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I could see that.

text: There was a dusty odor in his hair.

text: The wind that gusted over the lake was chilly, and carried the faintest hint of the sweetness of spring.We stayed like that until Nakajima’s breathing calmed and he stopped sweating.There was a kind of intensity in us then, but it wasn’t sensual.

text: Neither of us was in control enough for that.

text: But after a few moments, someone wandered out.He was an adult, perhaps thirty-five or so, and yet he was extremely small, like a child.

text: I wanted to see you so badly, but it made me anxious.

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Chihiro, this is Mino,” Nakajima said.I smiled and said hi, my mind awhirl with all I didn’t understand.There was something special in their intimacy.

text: They could smile back and forth without speaking, like soldiers who had fought side by side.The wind was beautiful, racing through the sky.If only we could live someplace like that, so high and lovely, free as birds, liberated from our worries.

text: But we don’t, and I have to confess that Nakajima was a weight on my shoulders.

text: Not a heavy one, but a weight nonetheless.

text: Until lately, I’d lived in a world all my own, and I didn’t like the idea that Nakajima might come to depend on me more than he already did.

text: I didn’t really dislike it, but I didn’t like it.

text: I didn’t even feel that I had to hide what I was thinking.

text: “Sorry it’s so cramped and dirty.”Nakajima and I nodded to each other and went inside.The inside of the house was as plain and tidy as a European country cottage, the kind you see in movies.As far as I could tell, the first floor only had a kitchen, a toilet, and a bath.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Mino led the way into the kitchen, and after we had each picked a chair we thought we could sit in from the mismatched group around the table, we gingerly sat down.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The table was perfectly square, like an oversized school desk.“I used to live here with my mother,” Nakajima said.

text: “It was like camping, like in an old French film—we didn’t have much, but every day we would gather up whatever we could find, and we lived like that, very quietly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Always looking at the lake.”“Wow,” I said.“It was hard sometimes, but in retrospect I had a lot of fun.” Nakajima had gotten a bit hyper, and his tone was cheerful.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “The house is so small, we used to go on walks every day.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sometimes we’d go out in a boat, too.

text: We felt better each day.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: People look so beautiful when their expressions show that they know they have a future.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I remember it so clearly, all that, how happy it made me.”Tears filled Nakajima’s eyes as he spoke.The whole house was still.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Outside the window there was nothing but the lake, hazy in the early spring.To me, it was a frighteningly desolate scene.Mino brought water to a boil over a low flame, and carefully made tea.I took a sip.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: A delicate fragrance filled my mouth.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: This was the most delicious black tea I had ever drunk in my life.When I told Mino this, he fidgeted shyly.“The springs here are good for tea,” he said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I go and get water every day, just for tea.”No way, it can’t just be the water, I thought.

text: That’s his only luxury.And what an enormous luxury that is.

text: He’s created a world for himself that no one else can interfere with, I thought.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: A world free from all external impositions.Mino’s bearing was sufficiently dignified to expunge the last traces of a middle-aged-lady-poking-her-nose-into-everything sort of sympathy that had managed, in some mysterious way, to keep smoldering inside me, until then.Good tea is eloquent enough, it turns out, to change a person’s mind.Nakajima and Mino exchanged various bits of gossip for a while, giddy as two schoolboys.

author: Banana Yoshimoto

author: Banana Yoshimoto

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was so lovely there, and so incredibly quiet, that if even one more person had been with us I knew the mood would have been destroyed.

text: But it was true, I could feel it—all it would take for this delicate world of ours to come crashing down was just a single extra element.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sturdy as the bond between us was, it was also somehow terribly fragile.“Don’t go away, Nakajima,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I mean, I’m not talking about Paris or anything, you can go to Paris.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just want you to do your best to stay here, in this world.”“I don’t particularly want to—to go away,” Nakajima said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Only it’s like there’s something inside me, in my body, that’s constantly telling me I don’t belong here.”“You’ve got to fight it, Nakajima.”“I am fighting, it’s just that I’ve lost so much, I can’t fight very hard.”“Don’t be a wuss,” I said.“Just look at me, though.
