author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m not into sex, anyway.”“Yeah, right, you can’t fool me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You’re actually extremely into sex!”“Now that’s rude!” I cried.My voice shattered the silence, and seemed to echo in the black night sky.Nakajima was chuckling.I sensed that he, Mino, and even Chii had something in common, though since Chii had just been lying there I didn’t have much of an impression of her.I saw it as a sort of desolate landscape, unfathomably lonely and hopeless, totally wrecked, its very foundation destroyed, but one that was being pieced together again from scraps.Where could they have gotten to know one another?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was slowly starting to figure it out.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It wasn’t anything more than a guess, but I had a vague understanding, at least, of something.It was so dark, though, I didn’t even want to admit it could be part of the truth of life.I still believed, back then, much more than I do now, that the world was essentially a happy place, full of the sounds of families having dinner together, the smile on a mother’s face when she sees her husband off to work in the morning, the warmth radiating from a loved one in bed beside you when you wake up in the middle of the night.That’s not how it was with Nakajima, in his world.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: His universe included everything dark, and that darkness was always there.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It had nothing to do, say, with him being a man and me a woman, it was a result of the different paths our lives had taken.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I thought I had a pretty good grasp of the world compared to other people my age, but that was nothing compared to the weight Nakajima carried inside him.Still chuckling, Nakajima took my hand in his, and we walked quietly on around the lake, heading for the station.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was peaceful.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We decided to buy a bentō box for dinner and eat it on the train home.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It felt, that night, as though each step we took brought us closer to the future.When we turned to look back, the lake had misted over.It seemed pale, vaguely warped.The next week, my mural-painting days got under way.I set out from the apartment at eight each morning, as if I were a construction worker on the way to a site.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because that’s when the light is best.I would plant a kiss on Nakajima’s cheek, then head straight for my wall.The first day, I painted a few frolicking monkeys.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: After that, I decided that I would paint a big lake on the left third of the wall.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Of course, I’d put monkeys around the lake, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Calm monkeys, and lots of trees.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: A monkey brother and sister, and a mother monkey and her son.I knew it would be painful to paint these things, but I couldn’t stop myself.A little girl came and said, “You’re drawing monkeys?” And that got things started: little by little, children began gathering around.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I seriously bawled out a few boys who were about to start messing around with my paints, and then I apologized, and after that even they slowly started to appreciate what I was doing.One skinny little boy with big eyes and a flat nose came over and asked, “Does it mean the school won’t be closed anymore when it has your picture?” Clearly Sayuri and his parents had been talking to him.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: People called him Yotchan, and he was taking English classes.“No, I’m afraid not.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Even with my picture, it may be closed.”“Then why are you drawing it?”“Because there’s a place to paint, and they asked me to paint it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Won’t it be nicer to have some pretty colors here, even if it’s only for a little while?”“It isn’t for art?”“Hardly,” I said, laughing.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Not by a long shot.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s just a picture of some monkeys.”“Um, are those monkeys ghosts?” Yotchan asked.Following his finger with my eyes, I realized he was pointing to the four monkeys over by the lake.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I had only sketched their forms, so they were just uncolored outlines, half transparent.“No, they aren’t ghosts.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ll color them in later on.”“Oh,” Yotchan said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I thought it was funny.”Children are incredible, I thought.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It never would have occurred to me to paint ghosts into such a happy picture.I kept mulling over the composition as I brushed on the colors.The area around the lake was going to be the most colorful, and I wanted to keep it balanced with the rest of the painting, so I would probably be doing it last.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I couldn’t leave those monkeys as ghosts.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’d give them some fun-looking colors, but nothing too loud, since they lived quiet lives.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’d use the happiest tones I could come up with.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And I’d paint in some tea, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And cake.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’d fill in the area around that harsh sleeping beauty with lovely, lovely colors.Surprisingly, Nakajima didn’t stop living in my apartment even after I got wrapped up in the mural and began staying out as long as the sun was up.For some reason, somewhere in the back of my mind I’d thought that as soon as I started working on the mural, he would vanish.Sometimes I’d have a dream like that, and I’d wake up with my heart racing, bolting upright on my futon.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Tears would be streaming down my cheeks—even I was startled.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I had come home to find that Nakajima was gone, along with all his stuff.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I rushed to the window, hurriedly slid it open, and looked out, but his window was dark.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was nothing to indicate that Nakajima had ever existed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: To think that it was all over, so soon … That was how the dream went.Each time I had it, I realized again that it could happen at any time.And yet when I came home worn out from painting, Nakajima was always there.Sometimes he had even started the rice cooker.Other times he was asleep, exhausted from his studies.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Stacks of incomprehensible books about biochemistry and genetic engineering and so on would be stacked up next to him, their pages marked with Post-its.Nothing about our days together was certain.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The only thing I could count on was that for the time being he was still here with me, still living.One evening, I came home to find Nakajima lying on the floor, snoring.His PowerBook was open on the low table where we ate our meals, so I assumed he must have fallen asleep while he was working.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I brought a blanket over and was putting it over him when something caught my eye.He had something tucked under his armpit.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: A hard-looking silver rectangle.It was such a bizarre sight that at first I couldn’t for the life of me tell what it was.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Actually, that’s not quite right.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Maybe I did know what it was, and my brain just refused to accept it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because it seemed so completely out of place, so surreal.It was an old wire rack for toasting mochi.A chill ran down my spine.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It didn’t make sense.It seemed like it would be painful to sleep with something like that stuck in your armpit, so I tried very delicately to slip it out.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But he had it clamped there so tightly, like a child squeezing a thermometer much harder than necessary under his arm, that it would have been impossible to remove it without waking him.I could see from the ferociousness with which he held on to the rack that it was extremely important to him, but even so, deep down, the discomfort I felt seeing it there lingered.I thought long and hard about whether I should mention it when he awoke.The thing was, I couldn’t very well pretend I didn’t know.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Besides, this was my apartment.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Should I slip out of the room when he woke up?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That seemed kind of odd, too.I wondered what it might mean.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Maybe … that wire rack was actually the only thing that turned him on?Did I love him so deeply that I could go along with something like that, if he had that side to him?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Would I feel absolutely comfortable with it?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: (After all, there are all kinds of people … I once knew a guy who could only get excited by goldfish.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He couldn’t masturbate or have sex or anything unless he had a goldfish in front of him.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: )I wasn’t sure.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The honest truth was that while I might love him that much, it was equally likely that I hadn’t yet reached that point.I was still worrying about this when, just like that, Nakajima woke up.He opened his eyes, bolted up in bed, and sat there dazed, unguarded, with the wire rack still under his arm.“Want some coffee?” I asked.“Oh, hey, Chihiro, you’re back.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I guess I must have fallen asleep,” Nakajima said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I didn’t sleep a wink last night.”“You can keep sleeping if you want.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s all right with me,” I said.“No, I’d better get up.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Coffee sounds great.”With that, he casually took the rack out from under his arm.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He gave a just-woke-up sort of yawn and sat staring blankly ahead, his hair tousled.Then at last he noticed that I was staring at the rack, looking like I wanted to say something, and he said, “Oh, this?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s a memento of my mother.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I sleep with it under my arm when I get the feeling I’m going to have a bad dream.”“Oh … I see,” I said, surprised at how easily the mystery had been solved.“There’s no particular reason I chose the rack,” Nakajima said, evidently sensing from my expression that I was wondering what it had to do with his mom.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I just held on to it because it’s something she always liked, and she took good care of it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And it’s thin, so I can keep it between the pages of a book.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I think it used to be my grandmother’s, and we used it in our family ever since.”“That was the best memento you could find?”“Well, I can’t very well sleep with papers, and I don’t wear jewelry, and stuffed animals are unsanitary, and I’d look silly wearing a woman’s watch … in the end this just felt right.”“But what made it feel right?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It looks like it’d hurt.”“No, it doesn’t.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s really thin.”Nakajima held out the rack, smiling.“It’s okay for me to touch it?”“Sure.”It was just an ordinary rectangular wire rack, a little browned from use.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Light and hard and cool to the touch.As far as Nakajima was concerned, it was just another everyday tool, like a toothbrush or a razor.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That kind of bewildered me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: How it was weird to me, but not to him.“You’ve got the hard version of Linus’s blanket.” I laughed.Nakajima blushed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “So is this really unusual and embarrassing?”It was such an adorable reaction that I couldn’t suppress a smile.“No, that’s not what I meant,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “There’s no such thing as ‘unusual and embarrassing’ here.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We’re at home, after all.”“I’m glad.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I thought maybe I was doing something crazy again.”Casually but lovingly, Nakajima closed the rack between the pages of a book.I think I must have been reeling a bit at what I had just said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because my mom used to say almost exactly the same thing all the time about her club.“There are no rules here, except that you have to sit properly at the bar when you drink.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: People can tell me anything they want.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Things they wouldn’t usually say, things that wouldn’t be acceptable at work—it doesn’t matter.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s what this place is for, after all: they come and pay money to buy themselves, their innermost hearts, a bit of freedom.”She said things like that a lot.She’d say it whenever a customer prefaced a story with the words I’m ashamed to admit this or You’re going to think this is really disgraceful, but …Her openness helped set people’s hearts free, including my dad’s.I guess, I thought, my mom is still alive, here inside me.“Do you mind if I ask how you can tell you’re going to have a scary dream?” I said.“Not at all.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Before I fall asleep, my eyes start moving really fast, and my head starts feeling heavy,” Nakajima said, his tone perfectly ordinary.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “When that happens, I know I’m definitely going to have a nightmare.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I suspect it has a lot to do with how my body is doing, like if I’m particularly exhausted, or if the air pressure is particularly low—stuff like that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I can’t go throw myself into my parents’ arms now, of course, and I can’t ask you to put up with that kind of thing, so when it happened today as I was going to sleep I just put the rack under my arm like I always do.”I nodded sympathetically, though I felt more sad than anything.That night, watching Nakajima’s back as he brushed his teeth, I cried a bit.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I couldn’t help crying when I thought of him sleeping with that rack tucked under his arm whenever he got lonely, ever since his mother had died, as if doing so were as natural as taking medicine for a fever, or having someone give you a scare when you can’t stop hiccupping.But what sense was there in crying?After all, he had found a rational way to deal with his loneliness.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The truth was, I thought, that I was insulting him with my tears.And so I decided not to cry anymore.But when I got up to go to the bathroom that night, the edge of the rack that was sticking out of the book Nakajima had put it in glinted in the dark, and that got me crying again.Nakajima was fast asleep.Suddenly it dawned upon me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He really isn’t the sort of guy who can just go off and spend the night at someone’s apartment, without giving it another thought.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: When he made up his mind to come here, it was because he really wanted to.I was still pretty childish in those days—the truth is, I really was a child—but I prayed then, prayed until my head hurt, that I wouldn’t do anything to betray his trust, and that he would go on feeling comfortable here, in my apartment, forever and ever.I had finished outlining the mural and it was time to fill in the colors; I no longer had any uncertainties about the finished design, which I was gradually coming to see in my mind’s eye.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: All I had to do now was keep moving toward that vision.I enjoyed going out, spending each day moving my hands, without talking.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: This part was the most fun.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Things progress most smoothly when the end is in view, and all you have to do is keep adding layers.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t have to think anymore, and things had settled down enough that I could horse around a bit with the kids.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The day before, I had let some girls paint an area pink.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It ended up being more trouble than I had bargained for because I had to go back and fix the places where they had gone outside the lines, but that was kind of enjoyable, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Fortunately I wasn’t really worried about keeping on a schedule.Sometimes I found myself utterly alone.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Somehow, miraculously, no one would come by, and it would be very quiet, and I was relaxed enough to notice.So what was I thinking then, during those rare moments when I was feeling perfectly at ease, all by myself, in the absence of any children and my student helper, when even the composition of the mural had ceased to concern me?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s not something I want to share.I lean against the wall, pour myself a cup of lukewarm coffee from my thermos.My butt is aching, there’s a crick in my neck.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I feel like I’m getting a cramp in my arm.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: My whole body feels strangely cold.As long as I keep moving my hands, though, I can forget all that.That’s when I notice, all at once, that I’m alone, and I discover the vast sky overhead.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: In the distance, the flag over the school whips madly in the wind; other than that, it’s as if everything has come to a stop.I prefer to keep the thoughts that come at times like that, as I sit drinking my coffee, to myself—the particular texture of the sadness I feel, say.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I prefer to keep those thoughts private.I’ve traveled a long way today, I often think to myself.“We’re having boiled tofu for dinner.”Nakajima was awake when I got home, and he welcomed me in an apron.The scent of well-boiled konbu filled the room.“You look like a gigolo,” I said.My hands and shoes were covered in all different colors of paint.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I threw down my bags in a rough sort of way, like a sailor who had just come into port.“And the lady who’s keeping me is a construction worker,” Nakajima said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I can’t imagine any woman coming back from the club she works at, all covered in paint and suntanned, with muscles like the ones you’re getting.”“That’s true.” I laughed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I guess I don’t look much like a hostess.”I had on jeans and a sweatshirt; my hair was tied back; too much sunscreen had left my face blotchy; and I had paint all over, including on my socks and next to my nose.“It always seems like such a waste preparing a meal for one,” Nakajima said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “A waste of food and a waste of time.

text: But I don’t feel that way at all when I’m cooking for two.”I stepped up from the apartment’s entryway and peeked into the kitchen.“Thanks for cooking,” I said.

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Neither of us took these moments for granted, and they made us truly content.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “After I graduate, I’ve decided I’d like to get a scholarship and go to the Pasteur Institute as soon as possible.

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It looks like I’ll be able to get my degree, so I’ve decided to go ahead and apply.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If I don’t make it this year I can try again next year.

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Nakajima could only do things he was really enthusiastic about, so it was good that he felt this way.“What would you do, then, Chihiro?”“What do you mean?” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I’m not interested in Pasteur.

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Is that right?”“That’s a pretty impressive array of useless trivia.”“I learned it all on TV.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s funny, though—don’t these things interest you at all, like what school I go to, and what department I’m in, and what I work on?”“Not really.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Even if you told me, I wouldn’t remember.

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Listening to you talk, Chihiro, I really get a sense of how lopsided ordinary people’s knowledge of science is.”“You think?”“You really aren’t interested, huh?”“I do remember that you wanted to do research on blue-green algae.

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Paris, huh?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I would like to go sometime, only right now I’m really enjoying my work a lot, you know?”“You don’t have another job scheduled yet, do you?” Nakajima asked.“No.

text: There are a few possibilities, but none of them seem to be in a rush.”“What’s the problem, then?” Nakajima said.

author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was used to this by now.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t know where it came from, but I had grasped the outlines.After a long pause, he continued.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I think it’d be great if we could share an apartment, and meals.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Since this is my idea, we don’t even have to go halvsies.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ll cover what you can’t.”“Halvsies.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I haven’t heard that word in a while,” I said, changing the topic for a moment.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Then, “I have the money my mom left me, so I think I could probably afford it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m sure my dad would help out, too.”Nakajima nodded.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “After all, when your mom passed away, your dad inherited that club of hers, right?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You have every right to ask him for a little money.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sometimes asking a favor is the best way to show your love, don’t you think?”He had a point there, too, though I’d been trying not to think about that.“You’re too cavalier about money, Chihiro.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Just not in the usual way.”It tickled me to have Nakajima lecturing me on practical matters.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I grinned.Lately, he was starting to speak more and more freely, in words that came from deep inside him.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And that made me happy.I’d do anything to help him keep moving in that direction.I was even willing to go see my dad, and be pleasant.One afternoon, my good buddy Yotchan came over to the wall with his friend Miki to bring me a snack.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Rice crackers, potato chips, and chocolate.“See, with all this color they’re not ghosts anymore, are they?” I said.The design was almost finished, and I spent my days staring at it, adding a bit of color here and there and redoing parts to make it more balanced.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was at the stage when all the different parts gradually begin to come together, to form a world of their own.“Poor ghosts,” Yotchan said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “They still look lonely.”“Don’t talk like that!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You’re scaring me!” Miki cried.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I hate ghosts.”“Even if they’re monkeys?” I asked.I guess even with the color, their loneliness still shines through.“Yeah.”“I’ve never seen a real lake,” Yotchan said.“I have.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I saw Lake Ashi,” Miki said.I listened to their conversation, marveling at its novelty.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: At the same time, I was thinking to myself that I had failed, they still looked like ghosts.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The kids could see that somehow they were different from the other monkeys.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Although if I was able to express those kinds of things, maybe I wasn’t such a bad painter after all.…After that, Yotchan and Miki started talking about some TV show, and I went on painting in the colors.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They were in the way, but even so I was glad they had come.When I glanced back, they were squatting down eating the snacks they had brought, along with some manjū Sayuri had handed out, chattering back and forth.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I took a swig of hot herbal tea from my thermos and tried to think of some way I could capture the brilliance of their exchanges, the colors that glittered in their words.My butt felt cold from sitting on the ground and my sides hurt from having my arms up in the air for so long, but I couldn’t stop painting.With each color I added, another rose up before me, and I would keep chasing them, one after the other, until the sun set and I couldn’t paint anymore, and then I’d go home and sleep like a log.Now when I thought of home, Nakajima was part of the picture.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He was always studying, and always stayed in my apartment, whether or not I was there.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I guess he really must want to be with me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He came over because he wanted to.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I could believe that, I felt, more than I ever could have with anyone else.Wherever Nakajima is, that’s the place I go home to.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s what lets me go all day without thinking about anything.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: About what I’m going to do with my life, stuff like that.Eventually the kids left, and I was taking a break, pleased with the progress I’d made today, when Sayuri appeared, making a beeline for me, her expression glum.She’d always smiled and waved when I saw her before, so I waited, wondering what was up.“Do you have a minute, Chihiro?” she said.“Doesn’t look like it’s good news,” I said.They must have decided to tear down the center, I thought, even with the mural here.In fact, it was a somewhat trickier problem.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Something that gave me pause.“We got a call from the district mayor, he says they’ve got a sponsor.”“A sponsor?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I thought the district was paying for this!”“The thing is, they were talking things over, and apparently this sponsor says that if it will help energize the district he’s willing to assume the entire cost.”“That’s odd.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It doesn’t seem necessary at this point,” I said.Sayuri nodded.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I know.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The catch is that he wants you to work his company’s logo into the picture somehow, as big as possible.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You know that sign on the roof of the huge kon’nyaku factory near the turnoff for the highway?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s it.”Sayuri showed me a picture.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was the most bizarre logo you could imagine: an incredibly ugly combination of colors, mostly gray, with the company mascot in the middle.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The mascot was a block of kon’nyaku with a smiley face.“Oh, my god!” I laughed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “You’ve got to be kidding!”Sayuri burst out laughing, too.We were both well aware that in this society, things you’d think could only be bad jokes actually happen all the time.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And so, wiping away a few tears after my laughter had subsided, I told her, “There’s no way.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I mean, I’ve practically finished the design.”Even as I spoke, I was trying to think of some way to incorporate a humorous take on the logo into the mural, but it really didn’t seem possible.And I had a sneaking suspicion that even if it were possible, the sponsor wouldn’t like it if I made a joke of his logo.“At any rate, I’ll try and negotiate,” Sayuri said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Don’t lose hope.”This sounded like it could get annoying.“Listen, why don’t I just quit, someone else can finish it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: With the logo,” I suggested.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Or you can find someone to design a whole new picture around the logo.”“Why do you always have to be so absolute about things?” Sayuri said, stunned.So I had to try again.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “How about this, then: I’ll have to put the name of the district in as a sponsor over my signature, so why don’t just we add the logo there, too, very small?”“The president of the company wants it bigger, as part of the picture,” Sayuri said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “But if it’s going to end up being an ad, there’s really no point in having you paint it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Right now I’m threatening them, telling them it will cost a million yen to redo the whole picture.”Sayuri grinned.I like her when she’s like that, so I tried to be as gentle as I could, so that I wouldn’t sound like I was just being picky.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “To tell the truth, I don’t think my pictures are particularly great.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And I’ve been painting this one knowing that it might well be destroyed sometime in the not-too-distant future.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But there’s a huge difference between not saying you won’t paint anything because it might be destroyed and saying sure, anything goes because it might be destroyed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I may not be much of a painter, but I don’t just do any old thing, like someone doing hand-painted movie posters.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Whenever someone offers me a job, I only take it under the condition that I can paint what I want—and I think I’m able, maybe only barely able but still able, to create murals that justify that freedom.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So for someone to come along, just like that, and … it doesn’t matter what it is, no matter how cute the kon’nyaku character is, or if it’s Pikachu or Gandam or Hamtaro—I don’t care, if someone is telling me to put something like that into a mural of mine, it means they didn’t understand my work when they hired me.”“I understand that, I really do.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s the whole reason I wanted you to take this on, and I take full responsibility for everything that’s happening, so you don’t have to worry.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just came to fill you in, not to try to persuade you.”Like the good teacher she was, Sayuri kept calm and inspired trust.“At any rate, if this turns out to be an inflexible demand, I can’t do it, I can’t work in a system like that,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “It’s totally wrong.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They’re asking the wrong person.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Tell them they ought to ask a sign-painter for stuff like that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m not disrespecting sign painters, by the way—it’s just a different profession.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I know I’m only a step or two above an amateur, but I can’t switch professions for something like this.”I looked at the mural.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Poor monkeys.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You may end up being painted over, painted out of existence.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But who knows?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Maybe Yotchan and his friends will remember that you were here, even if only for a short time.The thought liberated me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I felt as if the things I’d been clinging to were crumbling, blowing away in the wind, dispersing.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Leaving me free to go anywhere I wanted.This is nice, I thought, really nice.I figured I might as well take a picture, anyway, and snapped a shot with my digital camera, with the sky as the background.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: To preserve the joy of this special stage in the painting.“I’m sure there’s a way,” Sayuri said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “For starters, I’m planning to show the video of that TV program you were in to the people in the mayor’s office, and from the company.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ll try and make them see how valuable this is as art.”“Kind of embarrassing, considering the quality of my work,” I said.For the first time, though, I was beginning to take what I was doing a tiny bit seriously.It was hard to say for sure since the president of the company hadn’t seen the mural yet, but I had to acknowledge that some of the responsibility for what might happen lay with me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just wasn’t good enough to paint a picture no one would want to mess up with a logo.It’d be nice to study painting more, to see all kinds of really, really incredible artworks and realize just how minuscule I am.… All on its own, the path to Paris was opening up before me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I pictured Nakajima in profile, engrossed in his studies at home.I wanted to be able to have that same look on my face when I painted.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Not to run away from everything that had happened in a day, but to turn it all into another form of energy, make it part of myself.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s how I wanted my painting to be.But first I’d have to finish what I had started here.“Okay, and I’ll do my best to get featured in a magazine or something, to make myself at least a little more visible,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Middle-aged men are impressed by that kind of thing, right?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And I can ask the professor who advised me on my thesis project to write the mayor a letter—she’s a pretty well-known artist, and she’s from the area, so I bet her opinion will carry a lot of weight.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She’s the one who did that weird bronze sculpture in front of the train station, I think.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And on top of that, I’ll send a letter to the president of the company, along with some materials about the mural, making it as conciliatory and pleasant as possible, to try and bring him around.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If that doesn’t work, we’ll just have to give up.”I thought it was a splendid plan.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Unless he were incredibly wealthy and eccentric, the president probably wouldn’t want to pay to have me erase a mural I had gone to all the trouble of painting and then do another one.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I felt confident it would work.“I bet that’ll do the trick,” Sayuri said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I’m sorry, putting you to so much trouble.”“That’s okay.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ll give it a try.”After all, I thought, maybe this will be my last job in Japan.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I wasn’t necessarily determined to go on working as a muralist, so I really had no idea what the future might hold.Things like this were bound to happen no matter what kind of life I ended up leading, and whether they turned out well or badly, I’d just have to do my best, the way I would this time.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And inhale the sweet scent of the freedom I’d earned when it came wafting over.“Let me know when something’s been decided,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I’ll take a break until then, once I get to a stopping place.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s okay, I know it’s not your fault.”I had things to do, and I needed to cool down, and it made me sad to look at the picture when it was so close to being done, so I hurriedly packed up my stuff.Of course I wasn’t angry.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I felt bad for Sayuri, actually.It was only natural that they felt entitled to order me around—it’s not like I was a famous artist or anything.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And I’m not a particularly imposing person, either: they probably assumed I’d just go right along with their request that I work an ad into my painting.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I saw that.In a way, it really made sense.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That kind of willingness to give in is rampant in this society of ours.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: From banks to ponzu sauce … well, those are just examples.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The point is that people have found a gazillion little opportunities to profit in questionable ways, all over the place.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ve seen tons of cases, all across the board, where in order to grab on to those tiny profits people studiously adopt another perspective, keeping their true opinions to themselves, and no one takes responsibility, everyone just huddles together on some middle ground, and it all gets less and less clear, yet in the end everyone ends up being crammed into a rigid, unyielding framework.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ve seen the same story play out over and over again.But I couldn’t take it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The whole dumb setup just bored me to death.Here I am playing nicely with the world, trying my best to leave things the tiniest bit better than they were, trying to fly even a little bit higher—how annoying it would be to have to go along with this crap.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That was my take on it.If I were Sayuri, for instance, and the Infant Development Center mattered more to me than anything else, and if I were part of the organization, I’m sure I could have found all kinds of solutions to their problems, and I would have gone with the policy that was best for everyone.But in the current situation, going along with this new proposal would have gone against the essence of my profession.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If I were a stranger passing through this district and I happened to see this wall and the ad were part of the mural, I’d think it was pathetic.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Besides, I have to say I don’t think much of a company that feels it has to have its name plastered all over the place simply because it’s shelling out five hundred thousand yen.Right now five hundred thousand yen is a huge amount of money to me, but that doesn’t mean I’ll just do whatever it takes to be paid.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Especially not something like abandoning my professional standards, because that would throw the rest of my life out of balance.All this reminded me of an incident involving a sculptor I respect.This sculptor had been asked to create a sculpture for a plaza in a certain town in Europe.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: In the place where the plaza then stood there had once been a forest inhabited by gypsies, large numbers of whom had died during some war.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So he suggested he make a statue showing gypsies.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He was thinking of all the terrible discrimination gypsies have suffered.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: An open area like the plaza was, he thought, the perfect place to commemorate a population that had been subjected to the evils of the human spirit, whose true story had always been concealed, consigned to oblivion.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But the mayor and the citizens of the town refused to go along—there were still gypsies, they said, who grabbed purses and picked pockets and generally made themselves a nuisance to tourists—people like them didn’t deserve to be celebrated with a statue.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And so the whole project was indefinitely put on hold.That’s how it goes.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Things look different depending on your perspective.As I see it, fighting to bridge those gaps isn’t what really matters.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The most important thing is to know them inside and out, as differences, and to understand why certain people are the way they are.My job was to insist on my own perspective, right to the end, and in order to do that I needed to brush up on my technique.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: However famous you may be, these disagreements are bound to continue, and ultimately it doesn’t really matter that I’m not that much of a painter.Well, maybe it does.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If I had more confidence, it’d be easier to hold my own.That’s the crucial thing.The truth, sad to say, is that I still can’t declare with any real conviction that the people of this town would be better off with my mural on the wall rather than that goofy logo.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s the problem, I thought with a twinge of shame: I’m still too young, too green.Returning early to the apartment, I found Nakajima studying madly, his PowerBook open and a dictionary in his hand.“Early, aren’t you?” he said.“I got stuff for dinner,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “No need to make anything.”I didn’t particularly need to say that, but that’s what came out.“Oh?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was looking forward to making dinner again today.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s a nice way to take a break,” Nakajima said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “How about I go and get us some coffee from that place where they roast the beans themselves?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It would be nice to talk a walk.” Then, looking me in the face for the first time, “Oh, looks like something bad happened today.”I nodded and told him what had happened.“Yeah, it’s not surprising, given your low level of celebrity and how unsophisticated people are in that part of the city,” Nakajima said.“You don’t mince words, do you?” I said, impressed.“If you don’t say what you’re thinking, you end up lying when you really need to speak up,” Nakajima said.“Anyhow, I can’t draw a stupid kon’nyaku logo into my picture.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just can’t.”“Did you see what it looks like?”“I did.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s this kon’nyaku mascot with a weird blob of words above it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Very uncool.”“Could you stick it in a corner somewhere, really small?”“That would be fine with me, but the sponsor said it has to be big.”“That’s something they would have had to make clear from the beginning.”“You’re telling me.”“And even if your picture is still a work in progress, it’s like a sapling that will eventually grow into a huge tree or something—it has that kind of glow.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They’ve got to see that.”“More plain speaking from Nakajima … I mean, even I don’t see that kind of value in my murals yet.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s why I have no problem painting in a place that could be torn down.”“I know, but your modest assessment of your own worth and the decision to treat your work like a billboard are two totally different things.”“I’m with you there.”“Besides, they hired you to do a job.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They can’t keep changing their minds about what that job is.”“Exactly.”“How about telling them you’ll quit unless they agree to have the logo at the edge, very small?”“That’s what I thought.”“Do you have any connections?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Professors at the art school, say, or some famous art critic?”“A few.”“Have them say something.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It helps to fight authority with authority, I think.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And if you could get someone to come do a story about your work, write an article that would give meaning to your mural or something, that would make your position stronger, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And if you should end up in court or something, who cares?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sayuri can decide for herself where she stands.” Nakajima paused a moment, then continued.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “See, people like us are never at the center of things.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We’re always on the margins, and I generally figure it’s best not to stand out too much.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Most of the time we see things in exactly the opposite light as the majority does, and people don’t look kindly on you if you stand out.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: When push comes to shove, though, you’ve got to have something you won’t cave in on.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Otherwise, you end up like a recluse or something, cut off from the world.”Our opinions were so close I felt as if he were reading my mind.The amazing alignment of our perspectives made me forget how annoyed I’d been at the prospect of having to stop painting and go to all this trouble doing irrelevant things.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That feeling faded so quickly it was like magic.When something unpleasant happened during the day, I used to come home and pet my cat to cheer myself up.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Being with Nakajima seemed to have a similar effect, neutralizing the poison that had accumulated inside me.My old self would probably have come in without saying a word and tried to forget it all by having sex with whoever I was sleeping with just then, not talking to him about what had happened, keeping everything bottled up inside.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That shows you how much respect I had for my lovers.But Nakajima was different, I thought.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: This time it was for real.At this very moment, I was truly beginning to fall in love.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It weighed on me and it was sometimes a pain in the ass, but the payoff could be big, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So big it felt like gazing up into the sky.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Or like looking out an airplane window at the ocean, with clouds shining above it.It was so gorgeous it almost felt like sadness.Like the feeling you get when you realize that, in the grand scheme of things, your time here on this earth really isn’t all that long after all.There was one other thing I had to do.“Hey, Dad, I’m at the station now.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Do you have some time today?”I didn’t want to call him at work, so I’d called his cell phone.“Wow, this is sudden,” my dad said.“Well, the job I had scheduled sort of stopped unexpectedly,” I replied.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “It’s hard for me to get out here unless something like that happens.”“I can get away for a while in the evening,” my dad said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “We could have dinner in about two hours.”The restaurant my dad chose was this incredibly mediocre Italian place, and whenever he went there his Prominent Local Personage thing went into high gear.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I couldn’t stand it.But I’d asked to see him without any warning, and of course he’d be treating me, so I figured I had no right to complain.With a family as stable as mine had been, my heart certainly wasn’t scarred, or if it was, the scars were ones I’d made myself—now that I was comparing myself to Nakajima all the time I could see that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I thought I was pretty tough, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Still, I cried a bit at the station.The days I’d passed with my mom before she died were still there, it seemed, seared into the corners of my heart.The atmosphere of the station brought it all back.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I could see myself running to the hospital, glad to be seeing my mother again.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You never know you’re happy until later.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because physical sensations like smells and exhaustion don’t figure into our memories, I guess.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Only the good bits bob up into view.I was always startled by the snatches of memory that I saw as happy, how they came.This time, it was the feeling I got when I stepped out onto the platform.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The sense of what it had been like to be on my way to see my mom, for her still to be alive, if only for the time being, if only for that day.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The happiness of that knowledge had come back to life inside me.And the loneliness of that moment.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The helplessness.The fact that now when I came to this station, I could go see my dad, but not my mom.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’d always done that in the past, but now I couldn’t.“You know, the chef in this place spent four whole years in Italy!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Seriously.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Hey, kid, do me a favor and ask Sugiyama to come say hi when he has a moment, will you?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I want to introduce him to my daughter.”Just as I expected: he’d said it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: In my heart I was thinking, Please, I’ve already heard that story, and how could he “have a moment” when he’s got a restaurant full of customers?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I kept quiet.Before long a man in a tall chef’s hat came out and talked for a while with my dad, and he said hello to me, too, so I just kept smiling away.I’d be leaving Japan soon, after all, and probably wouldn’t be seeing my dad for a while.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: When I thought about that, I felt kind of attached even to his preening.After that the dishes started coming out: huge quantities of pasta that had obviously been boiled too long, especially considering that the chef had lived in Italy for four years, and tiny servings of the main courses.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I suppose he must have ended up adapting to the tastes of his customers out here in the country—he didn’t have any choice.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’d met some exchange students from Italy when I was in art school, and I had made a few super-low-budget trips to the towns they had come from.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Needless to say, none of the restaurants in Italy had been as half-hearted in their approach as this one.As I thought back fondly over those days, I began to realize with more and more clarity that I was seriously on the verge of going to Europe.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And I was going there for myself.“Listen, Dad,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I’m thinking of going to study in Paris next year.”“With a guy, I take it?” He didn’t miss a beat.I was stunned.“What makes you think that?” I asked.“I can see it in your face,” he replied.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “You look ready to be a mom.”“Do I?”I smiled.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Maybe I was more giddy than I realized.“Anyway, it sounds good to me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s great you’re even able to consider it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Bring him to see me before you go, though, will you?”“Well, if I can,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “You’ll have to wait a bit.”Nakajima was too weird, not the kind of guy you introduce to your family.“What does he do?” my dad asked.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Don’t tell me he wants to be a painter.”“No.”“He’s younger than you?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: A student?” my dad said.I was impressed at how close to the truth he was.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Parents are amazing.“He’s in med school.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We’re the same age, but he is a student.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He wants to get a scholarship to study at this research institute in Paris when he finishes his degree.”“I suspected there was a man behind this.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Can’t say I like it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Not a bit.”He seemed genuinely displeased.“Terrible, getting me to confess it all.” I smiled.“Well, once you’ve settled on an art school in Paris, send me a breakdown of all the funds you’ll need.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And promise you’ll come visit me sometimes.”“Oh, I won’t need anything—I’ve got the money Mom left,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “And you don’t have to give me anything to get me to come visit.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Of course I’ll come!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You should come see me in Paris, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And to tell the truth, you’re the only one I want to see.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’d rather not have to see your relatives anymore, honestly.”“No, I don’t like it when you have to spend time with my sister and the rest of that crowd, either,” my dad said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I hate seeing you unhappy.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But please—if I do send you some money, don’t turn it down, okay?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And if anything should happen, let me know.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Definitely.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If you get hurt, or pregnant, or you break up with this guy and start living on your own, or you quit school … any big change.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Tell me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And if you can manage it, introduce him.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Anytime is fine.”“Okay.”Thank you, Dad, I thought, chewing my mushy pasta.My relationship with him had entered a new phase.You don’t necessarily have to want to become an adult; it happens as a matter of course, as you go, making choices.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The important thing, I think, is to choose for yourself.Standing next to my dad, I realized that his body no longer smelled like a middle-aged man’s.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: All of a sudden, he smelled like a grandfather.That’s what happens when you live apart.We’ll probably never live under the same roof again.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The second that thought struck me, days that had seemed utterly unremarkable were made irreplaceable, unforgettable.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I came face-to-face, once more, with a time I had left behind.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: My dad had been part of the life I’d lived then, he was woven indistinguishably into the fabric, with exactly the same color thread.But life keeps flowing on.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Maybe if his business failed and he went bankrupt and everyone in this town abandoned him, he and I might end up living near each other.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If I were somehow to become extraordinarily wealthy, say, and I rented an apartment for him to live in.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was no way that would happen, I knew that, but daydreaming alleviated my jealousy.The jealousy I felt, after my mom died, at losing my dad to this town.Deep inside me, the child I used to be is crying.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Weren’t you supposed to drop everything else and just be my dad, after Mom died?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: How can you go on running the same company, as if nothing has happened, and go on hanging out with those relatives of yours?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: What did all the time we spent together as a family mean to you?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Was it just a game for you, playing at our being a family?But the adult I’ve become wants her freedom, and the truth is that I wouldn’t like it at all if my dad actually thrust himself into my life.And so, like a man and a woman secretly in love, we remain silent about the half-wish we each feel, that somehow we could live together.I guess this is one way to love, I think.Love isn’t only a matter of fussing over each other, hugging, wanting to be together.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Some things communicate, inevitably, precisely because you keep them in check.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The heartfelt feelings that find their way to you in the form of money and imported gourmet ham.Having the sensitivity to gauge those things is a real gift.Our negotiating strategies seemed to have worked, because things went well.I managed to have the interview take place just in time to meet the deadline for a certain magazine’s next issue.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The timing was perfect: people who saw the article started coming to watch while I was still working on the mural, and the fact that it was featured in a magazine seems to have convinced people in the neighborhood that my work must have value, even if did look like a child’s doodling.The letter I’d written and the recommendation from my art school professor had been delivered to the president of the kon’nyaku company, and he’d come to take a look at the site where I was painting the mural.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He was extremely pleased to see it was the center of so much activity, and he decided that it would be a shame to ruin the picture; it would be good enough just to put the logo somewhere at the edge.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I lucked out because he was a pleasant man: he had broad shoulders, and looked sort of like a block of kon’nyaku himself.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He asked me to mention the company when the local newspaper and a cable TV station came to interview me after the mural was completed.I didn’t really care one way or the other as long as the picture could be saved, so naturally I smiled good-naturedly and agreed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sayuri, who had gotten the knack of managing things like this through the process of negotiating and arranging my painting schedule and so on, told me that if she ever lost her job she would come and be my agent.“So it looks like I’ll be able to finish the mural after all.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Everything went beautifully.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Thanks again, Nakajima.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I really appreciate your standing by me,” I said.We were at a homey teishoku restaurant near the apartment.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was having ginger pork.“So it worked, that’s great!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I figured it would.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We’re surrounded by all these bozos who don’t know the difference between a mural and an advertisement, after all.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They’re bound to have a weakness for mass media stars.”There he goes again, being a bit too frank.Something in his bluntness reminded me of Chii.“I bet that’s true anywhere, no matter what country you’re in,” I said.“I’m not so sure about that,” Nakajima replied, taking a bite of his boiled mackerel set.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “It might be easier if you were dealing with people who see historically significant architecture and incredible paintings on church ceilings and so on every day.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I don’t know much about art, so I really have no idea how great those things are, but I’m really looking forward to seeing a lot once we’re in Paris.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I get the feeling that in countries with that kind of history, even researchers will take a different attitude toward their work—just thinking about it makes my heart pound.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I won’t even be able to compete, I bet, in all kinds of areas.”“I feel the same way,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “In Paris, I’ll be able to spend as much time as I want looking at paintings of the sort I’d have to line up to see for just fifteen seconds at the museums in Ueno Park.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There’s simply no comparison in the quantity of what’s available.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And I’ll be able to see as many paintings in churches as I want.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: After all, I’m most interested in frescos.… If I have a chance, I’d love to learn about restoration, too—there’s so much I want to do!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s all there for me to study, from now on.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I owe that to you: it’s only after we met that I’ve started wanting so badly to go and learn more about the things I’m interested in.”The restaurant was packed with students and single men; there was a baseball game on TV.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Waiters bustled back and forth, calling out one order after another.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We hardly ever ate out, so it all seemed very novel.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I felt dazzled looking at everyone, like a mole fresh out of its tunnel.I had suggested to Nakajima that I take him out to eat, even though we never ate out, because I wanted to thank him for being there for me during my troubles with the mural.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He grudgingly came along, saying that maybe it would be nice to go out for a change.Having dinner at a local teishoku place, for the first time in ages … that’s all we were doing.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Back when I was on my own, this scene would have been drearily familiar.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But since every little opinion Nakajima offered was linked to a whole other universe, the ordinariness of it all melted away, affording me glimpses of the unknown.“The thing that concerns me,” Nakajima said, “is that people might start offering you lots more jobs now that you’re getting a little more famous, and then you won’t be interested in going to Paris anymore.”He kept his eyes down as he said this.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He carefully picked the small clams out of his miso soup, one at a time, and popped them into his mouth.“If I did get offered a job, I’d certainly go anywhere in Japan to do it, as long as that were possible, right until the last minute.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I want to earn money that way as long as I can,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “But I’m going to Paris.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: My life with you is important to me, and I want to be overwhelmed, too, while I’m still not too old.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I want to be blown away by greatness.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because I’ve started wanting to become a better person, now, even just a little bit better.”“I’m glad of that,” Nakajima said.He had a habit, when he was truly happy, of not showing it.We sound like a married couple, I thought.Playing at marriage, playing at being a dad, playing at being a full member of society.Everything in my life revolves around people playing at being something.But that’s only because we have to be that way in order to get on with our lives.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Just because people are playing doesn’t mean their hearts aren’t in it.The schedule was pretty tight, and I ended up staying pretty late a few times, but at last I finished the mural.Sayuri and the center’s director and I took a photo to mark the occasion, and, as promised, I made a special point of highlighting the name of the kon’nyaku company and thanking it for its support in an interview with the local paper and on TV.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We took another picture with the children from the center, with whom I’d become good friends, as if we had all gone camping together or something, and then they took me to a yakiniku place to celebrate.After it was all over, in the middle of the night, I climbed over the gate and snuck onto the grounds all alone, and went to stand in front of the mural.Maybe it was because I’d just finished it, but it looked really terrific.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was the best of all my works to date.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was a boldness to it that defied the darkness, even when no one was there to see it.At last, a faint sense of confidence dropped anchor inside me.Now, I thought, I’m free to leave.The monkeys in the picture dashed around like they had no time to waste.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Little blasts of color radiated out, one overlapping with another, merging, like a rainbow.And then my eye landed on those two monkeys, one drinking tea and one in her bed, and something inside me shimmered.Maybe I should go see them.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: By myself … yeah, I’ll go see Mino and his sister.I’d take along a picture of this mural to show them, and talk to Chii.I was trying to remember what train line we had taken, where we changed, what that lake had been called, when all of a sudden I remembered what Yotchan had said.Ghosts.And I began to wonder.Maybe that place never existed, it was all a figment of Nakajima’s imagination.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Could it be that the two of them, Mino and Chii, were no longer living?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That Yotchan had been right?I shuddered.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That seemed so much more likely than that it had been real.I’m a pretty practical person, and ordinarily there’s no way I’d even consider such a thing, but … somehow the notion seemed oddly right.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I felt like I was lost, body and all, in a fog of memories, and the feeling refused to dissipate.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Nakajima had the power to make you lose sight of the boundary between what you had actually experienced and what you hadn’t—maybe it wasn’t real, after all.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Maybe in the end Nakajima’s whole existence was aiming somewhere else, not toward the light but away from it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I got that feeling somehow.I was comfortable with him, and to a certain degree I was in love, so it hadn’t bothered me, but I couldn’t help noticing that there was something in him that scared me every so often.Or maybe that’s necessary when two people are serious about each other?We try our hardest not to feel that, to sweep it under the carpet, but I bet it’s there.A particular variety of loneliness, like peering deep into the darkness.It’s only natural, when two separate universes touch.For instance, when I was a child I saw a lot of vomit, middle-aged women totally drunk with their bras cutting into the flesh of their backs, and even middle-aged men running their eyes lasciviously over my young body—I was used to it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And that was only the beginning.… It wasn’t hard for me to imagine a world out there in which murder was an everyday occurrence.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That wasn’t my world, and it wasn’t the world my parents had lived in, but somewhere, anywhere, all you had to do was peel away the skin, and you’d discover a path leading down into it.Everyone knows that hidden pull is there, but we go on living our lives, pretending we don’t.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We keep our gazes fixed, day after day, on the things we want to see.But sometimes we encounter people like Nakajima who compel us to remember it all.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He doesn’t have to say or do anything in particular; just looking at him, you find yourself face-to-face with the enormousness of the world as a whole.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because he doesn’t try to live in just a part of it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because he doesn’t avert his gaze.He makes me feel like I’ve suddenly awakened, and I want to go on watching him forever.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That, I think, is what it is.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m awed by his terrible depths.A few days later, in the morning, I set out for that town.Stepping down from the train alone this time, the station seemed even more forlorn than it had the first time.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The only sign of life in the dead of the afternoon was the supermarket, whose huge electric sign glowed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It seemed to suck people in: elderly men and women, prematurely aged housewives.I kept walking on and on along the single street that extended from the station and found the road that led to the lake.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The breeze carried the scent of water.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Passing a small boathouse, a run-down shop that sold fishing tackle, and a closed restaurant, I emerged from the woods onto the shore of the lake.I cared for Nakajima so deeply that I was shaking.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I felt it even more in his absence.Last time, when we had walked here together, the lake had been more beautiful than it was now, and shone more brilliantly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I guess I must have been in love already.The lake, utterly still now, seemed to have been abandoned by the world and its goings-on.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was no mist yet; the sunlight beat down almost painfully on the bare tree branches.I kept walking, heading for the red torii.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: My footsteps were uncertain, as if I were walking in a dream.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: What if it’s just a ruin when I get there, empty for the past hundred years?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I thought.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I wouldn’t have been surprised if it were.So I was relieved when the small house came into view.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Relieved, and stunned.Because Mino was standing in the doorway, waving.I ran over.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “How on earth …” I said.“Chii said you’d be coming, alone this time,” Mino said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I was out here waiting.”“It’s amazing she knows these things,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “And that you would have such faith in her that you’d come out and wait for me, like a little dog or something.”Without thinking, I patted Mino on the head.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He had the most adorably dog-like round eyes to begin with, and for him to be perched on the stoop like this … it was so cute I could hardly stand it.“I’m not a dog.” Mino smiled.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Come on inside.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ll make us some tea.”I smiled back and followed him through the door.Relief washed over me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They exist.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It wasn’t a dream.If anything, it was Nakajima’s bizarre mood that had made them seem unreal.The house was just as tidy as before, and yet it felt homey.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Somehow you always get that sense when you visit someplace for the second time, and that’s how it was here, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: This was a place I could relax in.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And now I knew my way around.I sat back and watched Mino as he boiled water and made tea.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There wasn’t anything unusual about the way he did these things, but his movements were very precise.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He took his time, but he wasn’t dawdling.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was like watching a master at the tea ceremony.“It’s no use trying to steal my technique.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s all in the spring water.”Mino smiled.“Maybe I’ll take some when I go.”“I’ll show you where later,” Mino said.The tea, made from leaves with a subtly smoky aroma, was so good I could feel my senses sharpening.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It had a sweetness to it, and at the end of each sip I’d catch a whiff of fruit.“It’s delicious.…” I murmured.“Life sure is funny,” Mino said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Ordinarily I don’t go out much—I order most of what we need, books and tea leaves and so on, online.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The supermarket in front of the station is really the only place I go.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The weird thing is, while I never feel any desire to see other people, I get all happy when someone tells me they like the tea I make.”“Maybe you just know I recognize good tea when I drink it?” I said.“That could be,” Mino said.I sort of knew what he meant.I’m sure that if I hadn’t been a friend of Nakajima’s, if I were a traveler who just happened to run into Mino on the road, or a tourist in the area who randomly dropped by this shack, he wouldn’t have opened his heart to me the way he did.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We wouldn’t have been able to talk this intimately.Mino and Nakajima were a lot alike in that way.They weren’t casual about things the way normal people are.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They didn’t see any reason to try and be amiable with people just because they happened to be there.Maybe in a sense their way of doing things was kind of sad, but it put me at ease.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because it’s normal.In most cases, relationships fall into place the second you figure out who someone is and once you have a grasp of the context that led to your meeting them.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: For Mino and Nakajima, though, that process was all messed up.Think of those kids at the center.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They’re honest but cautious; they would never come plop themselves down beside me and start asking questions right from the first day.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It always takes at least a week before kids start pestering me and getting excited.I’ve got more experience with life than they do, it’s true, and sometimes as I paint I start thinking, Look, ultimately we’re going to get friendly anyway, and once I finish painting I’ll be gone.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So why don’t you hurry up and come over?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: What’s the point in waiting?But just because you’re working within a fixed time frame like that doesn’t mean you can just leap over the distance that separates you.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The kids, in this case, are right.I could relax with Mino because he didn’t seem to have any extra baggage, and I sensed that over time, little by little, we would become friendly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was the same as with the kids.It’s more than just a matter of words—there’s always a physical distance to overcome.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We look each other in the eye, smell the air, drink our tea together, gathering up tiny sparks of reassurance.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And then there’s the matter of affinity.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: If Nakajima had attempted to decrease the distance between us two weeks earlier than he had, I bet I would have been turned off.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I probably never would have cried as I had, touched at the sight of his wire rack.“I feel like this could become a habit—taking the train here, making my way around the lake, coming here for a delicious cup of tea,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Would it be all right if I visited occasionally, Mino, with Nakajima?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Not to have my fortune told, just to come.”“Yes,” Mino said quietly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Maybe then our stopped time would move again.”The stopped time, I realized, was Nakajima’s, too.“Quite a hero, aren’t you?” Mino said in Chii’s voice.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Mino’s eyes were closed.Chii’s eyes, too, were closed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She was asleep, breathing lightly, her chest rising and falling slightly under the fluffy comforter that covered her.“Wouldn’t I be a heroine?”This time, no longer unnerved by her sarcasm, I could be myself.I could totally see why Nakajima had wanted to see them so badly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Basically, they were really nice, interesting people.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They had managed to build something like a solid, healthy household on a foundation that was seriously skewed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Here, keeping to themselves, they treasured certain elements of life, like restraint and dignity, that people in the city had long since abandoned.“No, Nobu’s the heroine of the story,” Chii said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “The damsel in distress.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You saved him from the prison he’d shut himself up inside, you woke him up and brought him out.”I sort of knew what she meant.“Go to Paris with him.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You two may well end up living there for quite some time, but do it anyway,” Chii said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “You seem to be hesitating, but isn’t it too late for that?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He’s grabbed you.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And you’ve grabbed him, too—he can’t live by himself anymore.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I think I can show you an image that will make you understand.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Here, give me your hand.”Looking at Chii, I saw that she had opened her eyes.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The color of her eyes was so deep I shuddered.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t want to touch her, but I figured that was just my instincts telling me to steer clear of anything too powerful.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And since I had come this far, why not?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Screwing up my courage, I took her hand in mine.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was smooth, and very thin.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The hand of a sleeping beauty who had nothing to do with ordinary life.“Close your eyes,” Chii said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Match your breathing with mine.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It seems like hypnotism, I know, and in a way it’s sort of similar, but it’s not hypnotism.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We’re simply going to share an image.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Don’t be afraid.”I did just as she told me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The dark screen in front of my eyes was blank.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But after a while, as I waited, absolutely still, an image rose up in my mind.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: All at once, just like that.It was snowing.… In a dark sky, like motes of dust, like bird feathers pirouetting in the air, ever so lightly, snow was drifting this way and that.I was looking down on the snow from above.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I could tell because the flakes kept tumbling away from me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Then, all of a sudden, I was up in a tree somewhere, watching the street below.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Gradually, I realized that the tree was just one in a row that lined the street.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was an ordinary paved street; no sooner had the snowflakes landed on it than they melted.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The only place they were starting to pile up, in a thin layer, was on the roofs of the cars parked along the street.I saw Nakajima in the distance, walking toward me, a heavy-looking backpack full of books on his shoulder.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I could tell it had books in it because of the neat, square way it bulged.Hey, it’s Nakajima!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Just look at him, he’s so cool!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I thought automatically.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The way he stoops over like that, the long toes in those shoes of his—I love it all.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s not logical.Looking more closely as he approached, I noticed that he seemed to have lost weight and he looked pale and unsteady on his feet.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He must have been studying nonstop again, without taking a break to eat.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: As if he were trying, by studying, to free himself from something.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Then, without any warning, he stopped and looked up.I doubt our eyes could have met then, since I was transparent.He slumped down on the ground and leaned against the tree.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was no one else around, just the snow dancing lightly in the air.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Nakajima was watching the snow.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: His eyes were lovely.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: His face wore the expression of someone confronted by something wonderful.Then Nakajima opened his backpack and slipped an object awkwardly out from between the books that did, indeed, fill the backpack almost to the bursting point.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was that old wire rack.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He put it under his arm like a thermometer and closed his eyes.“No!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Don’t go to sleep there!
