author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You’ll freeze!” I screamed.The sound of my own screaming jolted me into consciousness.Chii was still holding my hand, her eyes open.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She was watching me.Once again Mino spoke in Chii’s voice.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “That was a symbolic representation of Nobu’s past, and of his future.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Of what happened to him, and what could happen again.”“I can’t allow that,” I said, tears welling unexpectedly in my eyes.My heart was thumping, just like when I’d dreamed of my mom.“It’s important to remember that it’s not something that actually happened, it’s an allegory.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Though of course it could happen,” Mino said without emotion, just interpreting.But I caught it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The shade of sadness hidden in the glint of Mino’s eye.“All right.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You’ve made your point.”Chii, who had lifted herself up, collapsed heavily back into bed as if she no longer had the energy to sit up.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She shut her eyes.“I bet Paris will be wonderful for you,” Mino said, himself again.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Maybe living there will be even nicer than it is here.”His return indicated that this session was over.“How much?” I asked.“Ten thousand yen,” Mino said.“That doesn’t seem like much,” I said, somewhat taken aback.Judging from the atmosphere, I was sure it would be much more.“We never accept more than that,” Mino said.I glanced over at Chii, planning to thank her, but her eyes were closed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Then, looking more closely, I noticed a photograph of their mother hanging on the wall behind her.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I hadn’t even seen it last time.I could tell she was their mother by the shape of her body: she was kind of small and oddly proportioned, just like them.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She stared straight out of the picture in its plain white frame.It hit me that I recognized her.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I had seen her on TV.And suddenly I understood everything.“Oh, my god, Mino!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t realize!”He seemed to understand everything I wanted to say.He nodded once.I decided not to say anything more.“I think I should go,” I said, standing up.As I left the room, a feeble, high-pitched voice called, “Good luck.”When I looked back, Chii was still asleep.“I haven’t heard her voice in a long time,” Mino said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I don’t see why she has to use me if she can talk on her own.”“I bet she thinks you need a job, too,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Besides, talking takes energy.”“I guess there’s a reason for me to exist, after all,” Mino said, smiling.“What do mean, a reason!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You matter very much to everyone!” I said earnestly.Mino didn’t reply.His silence was exactly like Nakajima’s, and it hurt to see him like that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He was quiet in the way people are when they believe the world would get along just fine without them.I had one more cup of tea and then stepped outside.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Mino brought out an empty plastic bottle and told me to take some spring water back for Nakajima.Today, small waves rode the surface of the lake.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was a light breeze.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The boats looked kind of lonely moored with no one sitting in them, rocking in time to the waves.My mind felt numb, as if I were in an unreal world.The tree branches were swaying slightly, too, hanging out over the lake.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I noticed that they were cherry trees—lots and lots of them.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I pictured the lake when they bloomed, framed by a ring of hazy, whitish pink.“It must be lovely when the cherries are in bloom,” I said.“That’s the most amazing event of the year here,” Mino said.He wasn’t comfortable enough with me to come right out and invite me to visit then, but his manner made me feel as if he had.Then we climbed the old stairway to the shrine, where the spring was.Turning to look back when we reached the top, we were so high that the lake looked like an adorable miniature of itself, ensconced in a ring of greenery.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The boats, lined up in a neat row, were like toy boats.The spring water was cold and tasted slightly salty and hard when I scooped some up and drank it.There was no one in the shrine; the only sound to be heard in the pure, cleanly swept space was the calling of birds.It occurred to me that Nakajima and his mother had probably come here for water every day, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I pictured the two of them then, living their lives, clinging to each other.They were so hurt and they had lost so much that they no longer knew what was what, but the need they felt for each other was still love.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: No one could deny that.Mino spoke.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Perhaps to your eyes, Chihiro, this lake looks like the kind of scenery you’d encounter in a dream—beautiful, ineffable.“But that’s because you saw it for the first time through Nobu’s eyes.“We have all kinds of days here, just like anywhere.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The lake has all sorts of different faces.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And so it’s always fresh.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Some days the sky is clear and the water shines so brightly you can’t even look at it, and it lifts your spirit; some days it’s plastered with boats.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sometimes I’ll just sit staring at the snow melting away into nothing on the surface of the lake, and some days when it’s overcast, even the trees in our garden look dingy.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’ll be so hazy that our bicycles look like junk.“The truth is, time hasn’t really stopped for us.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Things are constantly changing, even if the change happens so slowly you don’t notice.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I go to that big supermarket in front of the station and wander around looking like a kid, buying packages of curry rice mix with anime characters on them, collecting coupons.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I buy things like buckets.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Or a toilet brush.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Ordinary stuff.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And I cart it all home on my bike.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You see that …” Mino pointed to a little general store that was visible a short distance from the lake.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “That store over there.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The man who runs it is part of our neighborhood association, so if we run into each other at the supermarket he gives me a lift in his car.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: His relatives are in Shizuoka, and in the winter they send him boxes of mikan.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He brings us a lot, every year.“But we don’t get any friendlier with him than that.“The priest at this shrine is a relative of Nobu’s, but whenever we have business with him we just smile back and forth—we never have meals, or go out together.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s extremely rare for Chii and I to really grow close to someone.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: People are afraid of us, because we have a different sort of smell.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And people scare us, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But we’re living our lives, just like everyone.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We live in this place.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Our lives may be warped, but we live them all the same.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: One day to the next.”“I know,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “And I’m sure that someday Nakajima will realize that, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That you’re not just a part of his past.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He was desperate to see you, even though it hurt him, even though it made him sick just thinking about coming here—but he had to find a way, right?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s how badly he wanted to see you.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And he’ll realize that if he feels that way, it’s okay, he can come.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I think he’ll come visit more often now.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Now that he’s done it once, he’ll be okay.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You’ll see more of Nakajima.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: All the time, again and again.”Mino nodded without speaking.Then he said, “I couldn’t say it well earlier when you showed me the pictures, but … thank you.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Thanks for painting us.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Thanks so much for seeing, the first time you met us, that even though we’re like ghosts, the two of us, even though we’re not supposed to exist, we are alive.”I had seen Mino and Chii’s mother on TV ages ago.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She looked just like them.She was notorious.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: People knew her as a terrible mother.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She had joined a group that had done horrible things, and she had taken her children with her.I don’t remember them having a father.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They had been born out of wedlock.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Maybe their mother didn’t know who the father was.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The news was full of all kinds of scandalous reports about her back then.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And if Mino and Chii’s mother was presented as an incarnation of evil, Nakajima’s mother was the incarnation of everything good.Things are never that simple, and I don’t see why it had to be reported that way.I must have been in elementary school at the time.If Nakajima had shown me a photograph of his mother instead of that wire rack, I’m sure I would have recognized her immediately.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He probably knew that, and so he didn’t.Nakajima’s mother was always pleading.“Please return my son to me!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I know he’s alive.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m his mother, I can tell!”Every chance she had, she would be on TV, in magazines, on the radio, at rallies.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She was always there, telling the same story.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Telling people about the day her son was kidnapped.Nakajima was a very bright child—too bright, in fact.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He was a little different from other children.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And so he would go and spend time at a special school.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The school had a summer camp in Izu, and he had been going there, and then one evening he didn’t come back.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Until then, his mother explained, again and again, their family had been perfectly happy, and there was nothing at all unusual in their lives, nothing that wasn’t as it should be.Not long after that, the group began turning up in the news.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It wasn’t quite a religion: their goal was to live in accordance with certain principles, and create a new, ideal humanity.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Naturally there was a sort of leader, and people gathered to listen to him preach, and then they established a commune deep in the mountains that was very nearly self-sufficient.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s the kind of group it was.Reports about this organization circulated so widely that even someone like me, who never watched the news, knew its name, if little else.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s how notorious it was.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: After the kidnappings came to light, the group may have disbanded, or maybe it still lives on secretly in some form.The truth is that in this world, things like that happen all the time.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I heard all sorts of wild tales from all kinds of customers at my mom’s club.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Many were almost beyond belief; many had to do with what was, in essence, kidnapping.Of course, on some level I’m hardly one to be held up as a paragon of normalcy.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: After all, before I turned ten, I started going to my mom’s club and doing some of the stuff a hostess does, so I was raised in a pretty unconventional way.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sure, I was protected by my mom and dad, since their influence kept customers from trying anything funny with me, but if I’d wanted to explore different avenues, my environment would have made anything possible.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: No matter how high-class you aspire to be, in the entertainment business you’re always trying to create a space where people can unload their irritations and frustrations, and I’m sure I must have been influenced by that in some ways.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That shadowy something is here inside me, just a little.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The whiff of something purple in the night, the sweet taste of darkness … it’s rubbed off on me, on my body.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Things were relatively okay at my mom’s club because her customers weren’t too bad, but even so I know just how slimy people can be, and how people like that are during the daytime.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They don’t get slimy at night because they’re drunk, they get slimy because they’re already slimy to begin with.I remembered hearing people chatting at the club about that incident, and watching reports on the TV there.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Only it had gotten all mixed up in my mind with other similar stories, and I couldn’t pick out any episodes in my memory that related specifically to Nakajima.Nakajima’s mother never, ever gave up.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She would go on every TV show and make herself available to every magazine, doing missing-person shows and having psychics look for her son, doing news programs, special features … it’s not an exaggeration to say that there was never a day when you didn’t see her somewhere.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She went on putting herself out there on a regular basis, refusing to let people forget.More than the event itself, she was what made the most powerful impression.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She always spoke extremely calmly, only said what she was certain of, hardly ever shed a tear, and always looked straight ahead.I could tell that until she found her son, nothing she ate would ever taste good, when she slept her dreams would always be nightmares, never light and easy, and no scenery would ever move her—she would just keep staring ahead into the distance, at her absent son.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She would go on trying to connect.Her endurance was astonishing.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was like she was reeling in a tiny, tiny thread, slender as a cobweb, which only occasionally caught the light, and she would never miss it when it did—that’s how focused she was.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was love, and willpower.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You could see it in her expression, as if it were painted there.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She had this look on her face that told you all she could do was keep gazing at that one point, holding on to her faith, because if she ever so much as wondered if her son might be dead, then he really would die.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Her face could have been the model for every mother in this world, or the face of a bodhisattva.Then, finally, they found Nakajima.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: All the energy his mother had devoted to the search, distributing flyers all across the country, putting up photographs, going on TV until she was completely worn out—it had paid off.A boy who had escaped from the group was picked up in a village at the foothills of a mountain.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Someone who had seen Nakajima’s mother on TV wondered if maybe this might be her son, and called the police.It was such major news at the time, I can’t understand why I didn’t remember it, even just a little.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I guess I never imagined it could have anything to do with my future.Wow, that’s awful, how terrible, I wonder what I’d do if it were me?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I must have entertained these thoughts for about a second, and then they vanished.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: After all, I had a mom and dad, and my life was just beginning.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s amazing to realize how ignorant I was.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And how innocent.Things keep coming around and around in this world, it’s all crammed violently together, two parts of the same skin.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I didn’t realize that.I doubt I’ll ever understand how the three of them feel, no matter how long I live.And ironically, it’s that inability that puts them at ease.So there’s actually a reason for someone like me to exist in this world.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Even before I start thinking about stuff like that, whether there is or isn’t a reason, in some place that exists prior to such thoughts, an enormous wheel is spinning, and I’m caught up inescapably in its motion.I’m its slave, almost.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m free to think what I like, but it’s all settled in advance.Ever perceptive, Nakajima knew it as soon as he saw me that evening.“Ah.”He must have sensed the turmoil in my heart as I stepped through the door.Because that’s what he said, the second I took my shoes off and looked up.And then he tried to act like he didn’t know, going on with his cleaning.Nakajima was extraordinarily finicky what it came to keeping things neat, and he cleaned the apartment so frequently it made me feel kind of guilty.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: When I came home, everything would seem weirdly sterile—even the edges of the books were aligned.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I couldn’t help feeling that I’d drawn the winning number in this relationship.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: What’s more, once he had started cleaning, he seemed unable to stop.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Maybe that’s what kept him going on this occasion, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Either way, he went on quietly cleaning.By then, I no longer felt like I could go on interacting with him the same way.As long as it had remained a mystery, I could have dealt with it—no matter how enormous a mystery it became.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Now that matters had gotten more specific, my imagination began supplying smells and textures.There’s a huge difference between “Something really, really terrible happened to me once” and “There was a period in my life when I was kidnapped and brainwashed.”Everything fell into place.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The terror that physical contact inspired in him, his fear of seeing his friends from those days, his mother’s seemingly unreasonable concern for him, his ability to cut his mind off from his body when he studied—all the delicious uncertainty was gone now, and in its place was a dank, oppressive weight.You know, I told myself, I’m not sure I can bear to hear the details—what his life there was actually like, why sex became so frightening to him.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And maybe I’ll never get over that.After a long time, I asked him, “Why did you say ‘Ah’ before?”He stopped his cleaning, surprisingly, and looked at me.And after that he was the same old Nakajima I knew and was crazy about, just as pathetic and as cool as always.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The curly hair at the back of his neck, his slightly stooped posture, the way he went around the house so quietly—it was him, the same as ever.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: His palms, too, felt just as dry as they always had.That set me at ease.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We had a history here, together, in this apartment.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That history was short, but it had nothing to do with his past.It was so flimsy, a puff of air would send it flying, but it was real.“I thought you’d figured something out,” Nakajima said honestly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Something about my past, I mean.”“How did you know?” I asked.“Oh, it’s happened with lots of people before—I can see it in people’s eyes,” Nakajima said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “And I was always on pins and needles about that, wondering when you’d realize.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Of course, part of me wanted you to find out.… Do I disgust you now?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Do you want to break up?”I took Nakajima’s hand in mine and pressed it so hard, so hard against my heart that I was probably about to break his bones.“Don’t say that,” I said.I used the sort of tone I might have used with a son.And like a child Nakajima mumbled, “I’m sorry,” and we went back to our lives.I cooked dinner, and Nakajima continued cleaning.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We worked in silence, like people the night before a move.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Like we were starting life over again.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Or like we had been doing this for a century already.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Setting all kinds of things aside, willing to go back to the first days, if that’s what it took, like Adam and Eve.Nakajima’s past would always be there, so the foundation could crumble at any moment.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s what happens, I realized, when people destroy other people.We had finished eating when Nakajima spoke.“Can we go see your mural?”“If you want to.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I don’t know—it’s night.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Wouldn’t it be better to go in the daytime, when you can see better?”“I’ll go during the day, too, of course.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just thought we could go now, take a walk.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m assuming it’s finished, right?”I figured we could go to see it whenever, so I hadn’t actually told him it was done.“All right, let’s go,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “It’s still early enough that the guard will let us in if I tell him I forgot something.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He knows me by now.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There’s a street light near the wall, so I doubt it will be too dark to see anyway, but just in case we can take that giant flashlight.”The scents of spring hung over the dark street; the stars seemed hazy.As we walked, Nakajima started talking.“I was going to a summer camp run by this school I was going to, and somehow I got lost, I ended up deep in the mountains, wandering along the highway, and these people picked me up in their car, and that was it, I’d been kidnapped.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: This was long before cell phones, of course.”The story had begun.The words kept coming, like water overflowing, refusing to stop.He’s like a broken machine, I thought.Walking on, talking on, his arms folded over his chest.All I could do was nod.“Can you imagine what it’s like to be kidnapped?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Did it ever occur to you that you’d have to learn to like your kidnappers?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because that’s the only way you can survive.“Do you understand what that means?“First, they erased my memory.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: With hypnotism and drugs.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And they made me believe that the place we were in wasn’t in Japan.“I was a smart kid, so I knew how to resist the hypnotism.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I had a vague memory of this technique I’d read about in a book, and I figured I’d try whatever I could, and somehow I managed to make it work.“What you had to do was practice a kind of autosuggestion, you make yourself remember a given person whenever you see a particular object, and since I was in Izu I knew the ocean had to be somewhere nearby, so I hypnotized myself into remembering my mother whenever I saw the ocean or if I found myself standing on the shore.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: After that I just let them do what they wanted with me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was scary, but in the end it worked.“Several months later, when we went down to the beach one very cold night for meditation practice, I remembered my mom.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It took a few days after that for me to recall that we were in Japan, and to think I might have been kidnapped.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There were a number of families in the group, parents and children both, like Mino and Chii and their mother, and I had gotten so used to it being that way that I almost took it for granted.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Their mother wasn’t living in the same room as them—the group had some ideological reason for that—but they put us together, and we all slept in a row.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Holding hands, like the three strokes of the character for ‘river.’“During the daytime, teachers in different fields would come and lead discussions and study groups and stuff.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: For kids and adults both.“At first after I remembered I got so confused I thought I was going crazy, but I waited a few days without letting on about anything, and little by little I started analyzing the situation I was in.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I came up with a hypothesis about what must have happened, the thing that seemed closest to the truth, and in the end I made up my mind to escape.“It wouldn’t have been a surprise if I’d gone crazy then.“I had to go wild inside myself, fighting to keep my sanity.“People try instinctively to take the easy route, right?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We shy away from pain.“So I didn’t want to believe that the people I was living with then, day after day, were bad, and my mind would drift off on its own, trying to think that the things I had remembered were fake, that they were the lie.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I hated the thought of leaving Mino and Chii, there was no ambiguity in that, and it frightened me to think of what might happen to them if I escaped and the police came.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: At times like that, your thoughts are inevitably drawn to the worst-case scenario.“Is this really a foreign country?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: No, it has to be Japan.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I was born here, I grew up in this place.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: No, that’s not true.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was kidnapped.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Kidnapping is bad—I’ve got to do something.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But they’re all such good people, how could I accuse them of something like that?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: How long have I been here?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Has it been a really long time?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I wonder if Mom is still alive … I was bewildered.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Is this woman I keep remembering my mom?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: No, I know she isn’t, she’s just a vision I created because I want a mom so badly … Everything got tangled up like that, the thoughts kept hounding me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I don’t say that lightly: my mind was really being torn to pieces, stripped of everything inside it, and I started getting very unstable.“So finally I got up the courage to talk with Mino and Chii.“And this is what Mino said, late at night, in a whisper:“ ‘I think you’re probably right, Nobu.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ve been living here with everyone ever since I was a baby, so I don’t really know about certain things, but I think you were probably stolen.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I mean, it’s odd that your mom isn’t here.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And this is Japan.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s for sure.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Even though everyone says it isn’t.’“He had no idea how it might affect him and his sister, but still he told me his opinion.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: In a sense, he was risking his life, and I can’t ever be grateful enough to him for that, as long as I live.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Even though it is so hard for me to go and see them.“The reason Chii is bedridden, and the reason I get so exhausted sometimes—it’s not just a matter of emotional trauma.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: All the drugs they gave us destroyed our livers.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Mino has gotten a lot better, but I don’t think he’s completely recovered, either.“Not long after the group disbanded, Mino and Chii’s mother died of liver cancer.“The house they live in now was originally used as a kind of combined storage and meeting room for the shrine, and that’s why my mother and I were able to live there a while, and when Mino and Chii’s mother died we decided to invite them to live there, without paying any rent or anything.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We wanted them to feel free to stay there forever.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: After all, part of me still isn’t sure whether what I did was really best for them.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Maybe they would have been better off if I hadn’t informed on the group when I escaped, and they could have just stayed there like that for the rest of their lives.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sometimes I wonder.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So I wanted to find a way to help them out with their new lives, and to protect them from society.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: My mom felt exactly the same way.”Nakajima’s arms remained tightly folded across his chest.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I knew the street we were walking on very well, and yet it seemed somehow to be detached from the earth, subtly distorted.Plodding on with even steps, I listened.“The group hadn’t been living in that place all along—evidently they were moving around from place to place, all over Japan, looking for somewhere to settle.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So all kinds of people were coming and going all the time.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It wasn’t at all unusual to suddenly see some face you didn’t recognize, or for someone who had been there to disappear, so it wasn’t hard for me to escape.“The thought that scared me the most was that maybe I’d keep going and going, but maybe I’d never arrive anywhere, and if I finally came to a populated area I’d find that it really was a foreign country, and I wouldn’t be able to communicate, and it would turn out that all those memories I’d had really were just an illusion.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t have a passport, so I would have no way of getting back to the ‘home’ I was thinking of anyway.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So I’d just have to go back to the same place and live there again.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Without any hope.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: What if that turned out to be the truth?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: These thoughts plagued me endlessly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That was the worst, it really was.“I started thinking that if that were the case, I’d rather just be dead.“If this little dream I’d cherished turned out not to be there for me to hold on to anymore, I mean.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because it wasn’t just my mother I was dreaming of.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was the background against which I came into this world, the scent of freedom that wafted through my life, supported by all the hopes and the love my parents had for me, because back then, when I was still a kid, things like that were everything to me.“My head was spinning, and the world before me looked so dark, I was ready to lie down right there on the spot and die.“But I had Mino.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: His words, etched deep in my mind, were my reality then.“I could count on Mino.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m sure I would have despaired even more if he hadn’t told me we were in Japan, probably in a place called Shimoda, even though no one ever said so.“He had been growing suspicious for some time as a result of information he got from his mysterious sister.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He was secretly afraid that the adults might learn about her strange powers, and then their mother would end up in an even stronger position in the group, and they would have to stay even longer than they might otherwise.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He tried his best to hide the things she said from them, but it was really hard.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So I had no choice but to save them.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I don’t know if they would agree that what I did deserves to be called ‘saving,’ though.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: After all, both their parents were part of the group—at least I’m pretty sure their father was, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m sure their wounds, the despair they felt, must have been a lot deeper than mine.“I think what Mino did for me, his noble sacrifice, destroyed any sense of stability he’d had.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And Chii’s, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And even if that stability was built on a lie, at the time it was still something they could rely on.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: After that, everything changed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And yet he wanted that change, although maybe he wanted it for us, in order to save me and Chii—and that act of love, more than anything, is the reason he can keep smiling the way he does, even now.“I trudged through the forest, thinking only of Mino’s words, and of my mother.“I get the sense that most people assume that when someone who’s been brainwashed comes out of it there’s a feeling of relief, that it’s like waking up, but it isn’t like that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You feel sort of dull, nothing is clear—it makes you miserable.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s the truth.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I felt like there was nothing good waiting for me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I would actually keep feeling that way for a long time.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Right then, though, making my way along that dark mountain road, I wasn’t worried about that, I was just fighting for my life.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Trying to keep from getting torn to pieces inside, trying to hold myself together.“Eventually I saw lights, and my heart started thumping, my head hurt so badly it felt like it was about to split, and all the scary stories I had ever heard weighed down on me until I could hardly bear it anymore.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I kept walking.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I stepped, almost collapsed, into the light.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I didn’t know what it was, but there was a fence around the space, and I had the sensation of something beautiful watching me, so I stumbled over in that direction, and there was a stable with five horses lined up in their stalls, looking out at me.“For some reason the horses didn’t get nervous or start acting up when they saw me; they simply stood there watching me, perfectly still.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Their black eyes and their lustrous coats made me feel completely calm.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I stretched out a hand and touched one of them.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I wasn’t afraid he would bite me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I just wanted to touch him, because he was so lovely.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: His skin felt warm, and then I caught a whiff of animal smell, and I loved the hard feel of his coat, stiff like grass—my eyes filled with tears.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The horse just kept looking at me, it didn’t seem to be thinking anything, his eyes were like two lakes, so gorgeous, drawing me in.“I’ll be grateful to that horse for the rest of my life.“That horse, with its wild, natural eyes, brought me back, made me all right.“I pulled myself together again, got a grip.… The place I was in, it was a small riding club.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I went and knocked on the clubhouse door.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: People who had come in from riding and the couple who owned the club were inside chatting over coffee, and they were pretty taken aback when they saw me, but the wife seemed to deduce immediately from how I looked that something was very wrong.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She told me to come inside and sat me down at the back of the room and made me some coffee.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The coffee smelled good, but even better than that was her smell—she smelled like a mother.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The kind of bodily, nice scent of a mother who never lets her children out of her sight, who always thinks first of her kids—I smelled it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And it brought back such memories, it was so warm and familiar, that I cried and cried and couldn’t stop.“ ‘You’re Japanese, right?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: So this is Japan, after all?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Please, call the police.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I don’t even know my own name right now, honest.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was kidnapped.’“I kept repeating those words, crying all the while.“And then one of the riders said he recognized me, he had seen my mother on TV, and so right away the woman’s husband called the police.“ ‘You can tell us the details later’, the woman said, and gave me more coffee and some curry rice.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was lots of meat in it, and I realized how much I had missed that, too.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: When I was with that group, we weren’t allowed to eat any meat at all.“And it came back to me that this is what a mother is, this is the kind of being she is—it doesn’t matter what the situation is, if someone’s cold she warms him, and if he’s hungry she wants to feed him.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I remembered that with such intensity, so vividly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was okay for me to remember now, I realized, and I wanted to cry, but I couldn’t cry anymore.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It took time for my heart to unclench itself.”We arrived at the center.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Nakajima stopped talking while I chatted with the guard.Then, as we walked through the small gate, I asked my first question.“And you and your mom went to live in that house by the lake after you got back?”Nakajima nodded.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: After that, he started speaking again, but less rapidly.“I was almost ten at the time, but after I returned my mother and I slept in the same futon every night, with her hugging me tight.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And for about three months, every morning when we woke up she would look at my face and burst out sobbing.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I remember the suffocating feeling I got, even when my eyes were closed—the sense that someone is staring at you, at your face.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I knew if I opened my eyes I’d see her, her face swollen from crying, so I just lay there, pretending to be asleep.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It felt so oppressive, I’m sure it was even worse than what you feel being with me now, dealing with the things you don’t know about me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It was so over the top that my father got fed up and left her.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s how bad it was.” Nakajima smiled.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I worried that she might go crazy, and so I asked if she could join me for counseling, even though it was really only meant for me, and we did go together, for a long time.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Even then, with her in that condition, she did whatever was necessary to protect me when the media came to do a story on us, and she told me we were going to make up for the time I’d lost—sometimes we’d go places, amusement parks and so on, and my father would come along, too.“Apparently my face was expressionless in the beginning, no matter what we were doing, I was always stiff, but that was just because I couldn’t find a way to show what I was feeling.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Inside, I was having all kinds of emotions, but it was impossible to let them out.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But day by day, slowly, over time, something was warming up in me, thawing.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I started to love my mother again, and gradually I went back to being myself.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I remember it all very clearly, that whole process.“And then, after things had settled down somewhat, our doctor suggested that we should go take it easy somewhere, and we went and lived in that house, by the edge of the lake.”That explains why he’s like this, I thought.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s because he experienced something so awful himself that he’s determined, more than most people, not to be a burden to anyone, to me, and to take care of himself.Nakajima continued.“It’s not like I was being abused the whole time or anything, I was simply being trained by people who wanted to create a race of superhumans, so in a sense they were all very nice, the meals were always good, with lots of seafood, and I had friends I could play with every day, so it was actually pretty fun.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But as far as the adults there were concerned, my relationships with them were all the same, homogeneous, there was no emotional involvement like there had been in my relationship with my mother.“I realized then, in the most physical way, that being logical and clear-headed isn’t at all the same thing as having everything the same, unruffled.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: When you’re in a state of homogeneity, it means you’ve lost yourself.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s how you’re able to get that way in the first place.“All that love my mother sort of forced on me right after I escaped, it was like a soup that was too strong, it penetrated too deep.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Her emotions were so intense—they were like gaudy clothes or something, with too many frills.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s how I saw it.“In the end, I think it was my fault my mother and father separated, and she died sooner than she should have.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That seemed to me like the most natural thing in the world, and I’m not thinking in some weird unscientific way or anything.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It happened because she used so much energy; she chose to do that, in return for getting me back.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: What she put into me was taken away from her.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She knew it would be like that, and still she used that energy.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I really believe that, even now.“Of course, I don’t necessarily feel like I have that long to live myself, and so back then it was natural for me to think, What are you doing, I don’t need this life, Mom, it’s yours!
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I didn’t have the strength to pray for that to happen, really deep down, the way my mother did.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I could never compete with her, I realized that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She gave it everything she had, squeezing every last drop of strength in her body into following the tiny thread that led her to me.“I’ve been broken in all kinds of ways, and so for a long time now I’ve had the sense that I won’t be able to make it through my life in a normal way.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But thanks to my mother, somehow or other I’ve been able to balance the books, and things have turned out really well.“Except it still makes me feel a little sad to think that the whole time she was searching for me, wearing herself out, I was having sashimi and laughing with my friends, and getting my first taste of the joys of sex,” Nakajima said.“Sorry, I cry when I talk about all this,” he added.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And then he really cried.Nakajima and his mother had spent every day together, like lovers, trying to reclaim their lost time, and that ended up being the best period of his life, and providing his most precious memories.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I doubted anything better than that would ever happen to him.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He lived knowing that he had already experienced perfection; that, no doubt, was what gave him a certain aura of sadness, and a sense of flexibility.“Emotions aren’t much, though.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I understand that quite well.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Just as my memories of living with my mother by the lake are the most precious I have now, in the days after I started living with her I was always thinking of the ocean, how much fun I’d always had there, playing with Mino and Chii.… The waves were always rough at Shimoda, and we would see each other one second, and then the next we’d lose sight of each other.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We’d laugh our heads off for no reason, fall down, get sucked in by the waves, and play so hard that we got out of breath.“When I try to gather up all the good things, I get an infinite number of combinations of events that fall under that heading, and if I try to gather up the painful things, those memories start coming out, and either way they’ll just keep coming, called up out of my brain or my heart or whatever, and none of it really means very much.“Just because things turned out badly in the end doesn’t mean that anything has changed in my relationship with my mother.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Everything is still there, the same as always: the fact that we walked slowly around that lake together, holding hands, and the way my friends and I laughed in the ocean, the fact that I was looking at a seagull then.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: None of it has changed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s neither good nor bad, as I see it, the scenes are just there inside me, forever, and their mass remains the same.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Of course, it’s true that sometimes the pink at sunrise somehow seems brighter than the pink at sunset, and that when you’re feeling down the landscape seems darker, too—you see things through the filter of your own sensibility.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But the things themselves, out there, they don’t change.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They existed, and that’s all there is to it.“Maybe it’s not even accurate to say things turned out badly.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sure, an accumulation of little incidents ended up ripping my life to shreds, and my mother swept all those pieces up with her too-passionate hands and jammed them together again any which way.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That turned me into a kind of patchy guy.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I have my life, I’m living it.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It’s twisted, exhausting, uncertain, and full of guilt, but nonetheless, there’s something there.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And that something is always greater than these emotions of mine.”Nakajima sounded, the way he murmured these words, as if he had only grudgingly decided to speak them.It was easy for me to listen, since I’d never been broken like him.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s how people are, pretty much, wherever in the world you might go.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There’s no need to forgive every mistake, to learn to like the bad things, we tell ourselves, and so we forgive just enough, in an easy sort of way.Take my mom, for instance.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: She was clumsy and terrible at math, she was nothing but a Mama-san at a bar, she had tons of plastic surgery, she died young, she had a child out of wedlock.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Or my totally uncool dad, acting like a dipstick in that cheesy Italian restaurant.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You need to have all that stuff, because that’s where it all begins.I’m sure it’s even harder for Nakajima.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Because the scale is so huge.But who knows, maybe if he can get used to the fact that each day is another dull repetition of the same old thing, being with the same people all the time, nothing but the little leaps of your heart to put a splash of color in the world … if he can get accustomed to that, maybe, little by little, something will start to change.Not only was the street light shining on the wall, but the nearly full moon was shining pretty brightly, too—we could see the mural fairly well even from a distance.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Certainly the colors would have shown up better in the daytime, but there was a kind of mysterious air to it, the way the outermost edges faded off into the darkness.“See, I painted everyone in over here,” I said, with a certain amount of pride.“Wow, so this is what it’s like.” Nakajima gazed at the mural for a long time, which was nice.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It made me happy to see the same expression on his face that he gets when he’s studying really hard.I felt how important the simplest things were, like feeling proud, finding something funny, stretching yourself, retreating into yourself.Clearly I was recovering, too, from all kinds of things.I wanted to get back on my own two feet first, and then lead him by the hand down the path we would take together.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Like the first time we went to see Mino and Chii, drawing instinctively closer to him, without any hidden motives.Gazing all the while at the picture, very slowly, I explained.My voice reverberated through the dark, empty yard.“This is you.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You’re taking it easy in the shade of the tree, eating a banana.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And this is your mother—she’s always hovering around you, smiling.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And here’s the lake, and obviously this is the shrine.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And then over here, this is Mino.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: He’s laughing, making tea.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: See how small he is?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And Chii, sleeping in her canopied bed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: A little monkey princess.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: No one else knows what it means, but that doesn’t matter—it’s a happy world.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: No one can destroy that happiness.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: People will see this wall without having any idea what it means, and then eventually it will be knocked down, and it won’t exist anymore.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But deep down in people’s subconscious, this happy group of monkeys, all of you, will still be there, just a little.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Isn’t that nice?”Nakajima nodded without speaking.“Lately I’m always crying,” he said then, snuffling a bit, so I didn’t look at him.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: What the hell?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was thinking, a bit ruefully.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: This isn’t love, it’s volunteer work.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: This should be the scene where the guy is moved and embraces the girl, right?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: C’mon!We stood there looking at the wall for ages, so long we started getting cold.Whenever I think of this mural in the future, I’ll remember this night.No matter where we may be, or what we’re doing.“I don’t really know how to ask this, Chihiro, but did they … did they look unhappy to you?”Nakajima had been walking in silence when he blurted this out, his voice hoarse.I thought hard.I had the feeling that if I lied now, everything would turn into a lie.There’s the surface, and then what we see under the surface.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Delicious tea, a dusty room, the lake glittering outside the window …I tried my best to bring it all together into a single impression, layer upon layer, like a slice of mille-feuille.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And then I answered.“They didn’t seem unhappy to me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Not at all,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “They didn’t seem especially happy, either.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: They looked like they must have unhappy moments, and happy moments, too.”“I’m glad.” Nakajima seemed relieved.Talking with him could be like a battle of wills, but I didn’t mind.In fact, I kind of liked it.“You know, Chihiro, it’s true.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: You’re really extremely unusual,” Nakajima said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “You don’t use emotional violence against people, or hardly ever anyway.”“That’s not true,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “I’ve got scary sides, too, I’m sure.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Everyone does.”“I’m not saying you don’t have any.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m just saying you’ve got less of that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: And that’s good enough for me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I was afraid of losing you, so I didn’t want to get too close.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But that didn’t matter, you were still there every day, in your own world, free from worries about other people.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There’s nothing uncertain about you, out there painting, moving your hands and your body, and I feel so at ease because of that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Except that you’re so optimistic—that kind of worries me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I get afraid, because I can’t trust that.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: But I’m drawn to you.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Sometimes I feel this urge to just go ahead and mess all this up, but I can’t, because I love you.”Nakajima smiled, just a little.“It’s great you can talk like that now, isn’t it?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: That’s progress,” I said truthfully.“Hmph.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’m not going to Paris with you if you’re going to be like that,” he said, sounding like a child.“All right.” I laughed.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Why don’t you go by yourself, then?”“That’s fine with me.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ll go all alone, and I’ll be waiting.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’ve been thinking, though—sometime do you think you’d come to Shimoda with me?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: I’d like to go visit that place eventually, and go to that riding club and say thank you to the people there, and above all to the horses.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It would still be too hard for me to do that now, though.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There’s no way, it’d be totally impossible.”“Why don’t we go when we come back from Paris for a visit, then, just make it part of the trip?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: We could go swimming together if we go in the summer.”Nakajima and I ambled off through the familiar neighborhood, just like always, chatting back and forth—not in a particularly happy way, but not in a sad way, either.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: There was a real sense of comfort, and yet at the same time it felt oddly tense.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: The feeling that every little thing we said, these conversations, at any moment they could stop being possible, and so they were precious, it was that feeling, and the sense of the miracle of this shared moment, here and now.Why were we so far apart, even when we were together?It was a nice loneliness, like the sensation of washing your face in cold water.“But before we do that,” I said, “let’s go back to the lake, to see Mino and Chii.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Let’s go see the lake when the cherry trees are in bloom, all around it.”“You’d go again?
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Really?” Nakajima said.“If we go enough, maybe things will be all right,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “All kinds of things.”Here we were, two ridiculously fragile people, sliding along on a very thin layer of ice all the time, each of us ready to slip and take the other down at any moment, the most unsteady of couples—and yet I believed what I had said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: It would be all right.Going along like that, I felt like we were high above the clouds, shining.“I’m sure they’d like that, too,” Nakajima said.“Maybe someday I’ll even be able to see Chii when she’s better, up and about.”That was unlikely, of course, but there’s nothing wrong with being a little hopeful.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: Who says you can’t warm your frozen limbs in the faint heat of a flicker of hope?“For the time being, let’s go back home and I’ll make us some tea with some really good water,” I said.
author: Banana Yoshimoto

text: “Even if it won’t be as delicious as Mino’s.”
author: Banana Yoshimoto
